NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return, and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Almost every day letters are received by the Correspondence Branch from teachers who neglect to state the name or names of the students to whom their letters refer. Before we can answer most of the questions asked, it is necessary that we know the name or names of the student or students concerned. As approximately 1750 students are enrolled annually with the Correspondence Branch and as approximately 300 teachers receive correspondence lessons for use as "lesson helps", it is quite difficult (and sometimes impossible) to locate the record card and the correspondence concerning any particular student or teacher unless his (or her) name is known.

In order that we may be able to answer correspondence more promptly, we request teachers to assist us by stating the name of every student about whom they write and also the grade and the school in which each is enrolled.

If students are enrolled for correspondence instruction in foreign languages only, they should be referred to as "Foreign Language Students" but if they are enrolled for courses in any other subjects as well as French or Latin, do not refer to them as "Foreign Language Students".

If teachers who are using our courses to assist them in their teaching write us concerning such courses, we should be pleased if they would state in their letters that they are receiving "lesson helps".

Teachers should not refer to correspondence students enrolled in their schools as "my students", "Billie", "Mary", etc., but should state their names in full.

Examples:
Re: John W. Smith - Grade IX(X, or XII).
Re: G. William Jones - Grade IX(X or XI) Foreign Language Student.
Re: Grade IX (X, XI, or XII) Lesson Helps.

Teachers should sign their letters as follows:

Roy W. Black or (Miss) Ruth W. Black or (Miss) Margaret Black
Teacher, Winnipeg, S.D. No. 1 Teacher, Winnipeg, S.D. No. 1 Teacher, Winnipeg, S.D. No. 1

RE: LETTERS TO THE CORRESPONDENCE BRANCH FROM STUDENTS

When any correspondence student writes about his own course, he should indicate below his signature that he is a correspondence student, the grade in which he is enrolled, and also the name of the school which he attends or, in the case of home study students, the school district in which he lives.

Correspondence students should sign their letters as in the following examples:

John W. Smith or (Miss) Ruth W. Black
Grade IX (or XII) Correspondence Student, Grade IX (or XII) Correspondence Student,
Winnipeg, S.D. No. 1 Winnipeg, S.D. No. 1

Students taking foreign languages with other correspondence subjects should sign their letters as above but those who are enrolled for a foreign language only should sign their letters as follows:

(Miss) Alice A. Brown or George A. Brown
Grade IX (or XII) Foreign Language Student Grade IX (or XII) Foreign Language Student
Winnipeg, S.D. No. 1 Winnipeg, S.D. No. 1

"Canadian Parade Readers are recommended instead of those in use, which have no Canadian material, but a great deal that touches on American points of view and American philosophy. In Grade IV, Up and Away, the Manitoba reader is recommended".

We are arranging to forward you the readers as shown on the attached list as recommended by Mr. Warkentin.

It is noted from the file that we have forwarded you the following readers:

- 24 copies Tales to Tell (Grade 4)
- 24 " Workbooks Tales to Tell
- 18 " Stories for Everyday (Grade 5)
- 12 " Treasure Trove (Grade 6)
The Department is anxious that the Indian School teachers use the Canadian Reading Development Series as much as possible. However, we are not stating definitely that the use of Corona readers is being dispensed with. Therefore, it will be in order for you to continue to use these as supplementary readers. If you feel that you have no use for the Corona readers you may forward them to this office for use elsewhere.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Mr Olson,

We have received recently an order from the Man. Text Bureau but an error has been made in either ordering or forwarding same.

About fifteen days ago, or more, we have received Arithmetic Work Books for our grades three and four. "Reids" and sufficiently. Again last week another order came in from the Man. Text Bureau and 36 "Opportunity" Arithmetic work books were sent in for grade four, but none for grade seven or eight.

May we return grade four Work Books and request 16 Arithmetic Work Books for grade seven. We would prefer the "Reids", four Arithmetic Work Books for grade eight would be sufficient.

If the "Key" to these work books cannot be supplied as we have asked may we return all our "Opportunity Work Books" and exchange these for the "Reids", as we have the Answers to these.

I have also asked for 3 doz. New Canadian Geographies, ours date from 1925. Two wars since have made quite an alteration in map work. Perhaps the matter was overlooked. May I ask you to see about the latter.

Thanking you in anticipation, with kind regards, I am,
dear Olson.

Yours gratefully,

(Signed) Sister Mary of Lourdes, M.O.

Mr. B.E. Olson,

Selkirk, Man.,

With reference to the requisition for school supplies for the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, it is noted that the Principal has 30 boxes of chalk in stock and is requesting twelve more boxes.

Our records indicate that chalk was provided to this school during the past year at the rate of 12 boxes a year. Would you please ascertain from the Principal how he accumulated this large stock of chalk and why more chalk is required in view of the large stock.

The Principal has also requested only 72 pencils for this school where the enrolment is approximately 114. Please advise whether this number is sufficient as it seems to be a small quantity for a school of this size.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.

MFT/HM
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Citizenship & Immigration,
Ottawa, Canada.

Att'nt Philip Phelan - Supt. of Education

I would refer to your letter of February 14th - your file 125/13-1-579 - re supplies to the Fort Alexander Residential School.

The principal of the school has been contacted and he advises that in passed years the supply of black-board chalk, pencils, scribblers and erasers were never sufficient from the Department and some of these supplies were purchased at their own expense. He still would like to receive the chalk as ordered and will you kindly substantially increase the pencil order. It is quite obvious that seventy-two pencils is insufficient for a residential school with an enrollment sometimes as high as one hundred and thirty-two pupils.

Bd. Olson,
Supt., Glandeboye Agency.

I beg to inform you that the Department has decided to assume obligation for an expenditure of $1000.00 towards the cost of building a suitable boat and equipping it with a satisfactory gasoline engine, for use of the Fort Alexander Boarding School. In submitting his application the Rev. Principal stated that a three cylinder 12 H.P. gasoline engine (Canadian Fairbanks Morse Make) would be required.

I have to request that you will consult with Rev. Father Bonsquet regarding the building of the boat in question, and purchase the necessary material and see that the boat is built properly by experienced men.

The following firms in addition to any other you wish should be asked to submit prices for the gasoline engine, viz:-

J.H. Ashdown Hardware Co., 157 Bannatyne Ave., Winnipeg
Babson Bros. of Canada Ltd., 301 Keewayden Bldg.
Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co.Ltd., 300 Princess St.
Cran Limited, 93 Lombard St.
John Deere Plow Co., Ltd., 110 Princess St.
International Harvester Co. of Ca., 782 Main St.
Massey-Harris Co., Ltd., 294 William Ave.
Brandon Machine Implement Works Brandon.
Brandon Pump & Windmill Works Brandon.

You should also quotations from the local dealers for the lumber and other materials required.

In selecting the engine you should be particular in picking out the most suitable, even if the price is a little higher than other makes, provided you can justify your selection by valid explanation.

Kindly attend to this matter with the least possible delay.

Yours truly,

J.R. Bunn Esq. Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.

F.H. Pegot, Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

This "Acadia" Two-cylinder Medium Duty Motor has been designed, constructed and tested to meet the most exacting requirements of those branches of marine work where utmost reliability — consistency of performance — ease of handling — freedom from break-down — fuel and general efficiency are positively demanded. The very best tried and proven engineering principles have been closely followed; and this model will meet the demands of the fisherman or commercial man where space is to be considered, where speed is an object and where maximum efficiency must be developed at low operating costs.

The normal rotational speed is sufficiently high to develop best speed without excessive load to propeller, thereby assuring propeller efficiency.

This engine will also fill the needs and wants of those wishing to use a four cycle engine to replace the smaller two cycle now in use, to be insured of the greater power by a saving of fuel and to cover greater distances in less time. Durability, Accessibility and Efficiency are the features which satisfy the most exacting users as to glancing points.

The special features of accessibility are removable Cylinder Heads, giving quick access to the Cylinders and Pistons for the removal of carbon deposits. Through the combination of the removable head and easy access to the Crank-case Cover Connections, the Piston Rods are removed through the top of the cylinder without disturbing the Cylinders. A removable Cam Shaft through the side of the Base is a special feature, and every provision has been made for convenient inspection and adjustment. Last but not least, the crank Case and Reverse Housing afford easy access to the Bearings and Speed adjusting screws to the Reverse Gear. Passovers are provided for leading the water to the Cylinder Heads, thereby preventing water from entering the Cylinders.

The efficiency of this design has undergone the most rigid tests which showed at least ten per cent more power than the rating, and economy in fuel consumption reduced to a minimum.

The lubrication is mechanical and positive. A Compression Relief Lever is provided for holding open the Exhaust Valves to enable easy starting.

Winnipeg, 30th December, 1921.

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Sir,

I am enclosing a statement covering the cost of a Baking Machine purchased by the Fort Alexander Indian Boarding School.

In my letter of the 28th July, 1921, bearing on this matter I pointed out that the necessary authority to purchase this, for and on account of the Department, was lacking.

However the Reverend Principal has submitted the statement, and I am now placing the matter for consideration before the Department. The Machine has proven to be very useful and labor-saving.

Please return the statement with such instructions, as the case will receive for my further guidance in this matter.

I have the honor to be,
your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir,

Since about 6 months, we have a great deal of trouble with our storing batteries giving light to our School. It is impossible today to charge them right, on account of sediment being at the bottom of jars. According to information received from specialist men, the plates of these batteries have to be washed and fixed properly the soonest possible. Some plates are almost dead already; but the greatest part are still good enough to be used again after a good washing. This work has to be done without delay.

I cannot tell the exact amount of expenses for that kind of work, but I believe it will be in all in the neighborhood of $300.00. I ask the Indian Department to help us to put these batteries in a good shape.

Our Indian Inspector, Mr. Bunn, has seen our batteries and has promised to write you about them: this was in the beginning of January. But I knew he has been away from his office; and I believe nothing has been done yet. Although we have to repair our batteries without any more delay.
if we do not want to lose them entirely. So I beg to ask you an answer in the earliest convenience. Supposing you cannot give us assistance this year, for lack of funds; please, Dear Sir, be kind enough to premise some for next year, and have it included in the estimates of the Government.

Hoping to receive a satisfactory answer,

I remain, Sir,

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Winnipeg...23rd February, 1922.

The Assistant Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.,

Sir,-

I have to acknowledge your letter number and date as given above.

This refers to the storage batteries for the lighting plant at the Fort Alexander Indian Boarding School in January.

I saw this plant/when I was at Fort Alexander, the Rev'd Principal wanted me to ask the Department to take up the matter of repairs. I suggested that he should write direct to the Department, and that I would very likely be asked to report, and that I would then deal with the matter. This has happened.

The Batteries have gone into their present condition, as far as I am able to judge, and I believe I am correct, because they were not handled as they should have been. The storage batteries were in very poor shape and almost useless when I saw them in January.

The Reverend Principal brought the battery to the city, on the 16th instant, to be examined by the people who make this battery. I suggested this was his only way to get quick action towards putting his battery in shape. In a letter that I wrote to him on the 4th Feb. 1922, I also told him that I was not able to say what the Department would do to assist to take care of the expense, but feared that the cost would fall on him.

I have made inquiry as to cost of repairing the battery and putting it in good condition. The Globalite Battery Co., Ltd. of Winnipeg, are the makers of this battery, their charge is the most reasonable one for this work. The cost of renewing the elements and plates is $309.00. The repairs have been made, and the battery shipped back to the Indian Boarding School at Fort Alexander. I beg to recommend that the cost of repairs be taken care of by the Department, and that cost of transporting the battery be cared for by the School management.

I saw the Reverend Principal in my office on Tuesday 21st instant, and we discussed this matter of the battery. He then informed me that he had written to the Department, as I had suggested to him. During our discussion he informed me that he expected to use the services of a brother of his church, who was an expert in handling batteries, when he would be
he re-installing the battery after it had been repaired, and I then suggested to the Reverend Principal that I thought it might be a wise policy to adopt, if he would arrange to have his brother examine his battery from time to time, to check up its condition, to instruct them the best way to handle the battery, as I was sure this would be the most economical way to provide against a recurrence of experience he has just gone through.

The operation of the battery was the cause of the trouble, the plant furnished was in first class shape, from the contractor who put in this plant, to start with.

I have the honor to be,
your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Note. I was in touch with this matter closely, and I was able on that account to reply promptly to your letter in this reference. I wanted the Reverend Principal to take up the matter, in the way it has been, as I felt this left me free to deal with business better.
The Reverend Principal of Fort Alexander Indian Boarding School reported that the storage batteries supplying electric light to that institution were badly in need of repair and that they were having great difficulty in lighting their building.

Inspector Bunn was written to and asked to report on same, and to advise the estimated cost of the necessary repairs. The report received from Mr. Bunn is to the effect that the batteries are practically worn out and that it would cost $309.00 to put them in good working condition. He states that these repairs have already been done and recommends that the Department pay the account, the school authorities to pay all transportation charges of the batteries from Fort Alexander to Winnipeg and return.

The Principal of the school is making arrangements for a brother who thoroughly understands the operating of the electric lighting system, to look after the installation and to see that the batteries are kept properly charged.

I beg to recommend that Mr. Bunn be authorized to forward the account for the repairing of these batteries for payment by the Department.
Ottawa, March 3, 1922.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge yours of the 23rd ultimo, referring to the repairing of the batteries at the Fort Alexander Indian Boarding School. I have noted that, at your suggestion, the Rev. Principal sent the batteries to Winnipeg to be examined and repaired, and that the cost of renewing the elements and plates was $309.00.

In reply, I beg to state that the appropriation for school purposes has been completely assigned for this fiscal year; but the account will be further considered, if proper certified vouchers are forwarded to Ottawa by you at the beginning of the next fiscal year.

It is extremely difficult for the Department to make payment of such claims on our appropriation, when authorization has not been given. In the future, if at all possible, before expenditure is incurred principals and others must understand that authority must be received if they expect the Department of Indian Affairs to settle the account.

However, if you see fit to recommend the payment of this item of $309.00, you should submit to the Department certified vouchers during the month of April. Further consideration will be given to the matter at that time.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Extract from Inspector's Report on the FORT ALEXANDER BOARDING SCHOOL. February 16, 1922. 125-1-16

The laundry building is a frame building placed on a concrete foundation. The height is a basement and ground floor. In the basement is the washing room. On the ground floor is the drying room. The accommodation is ample if the building was in a proper and good condition. The building is of poor construction. The concrete foundation is in bad shape. It is very badly cracked in several places and these cracks extend right through the wall. These cracks are a source of cold in the winter and of more or less moisture in the summer. This moisture that comes in the summer remains and freezes in the winter and causes heaving and twisting that impairs the building in a serious manner. Owing to this condition, the heating arrangement, which is furnished by an extension of the heating pipes of the heating system of the main building is put out of working order so that the laundry is always very cold and uncomfortable in winter. A certain amount of damage is caused to the water pipes by the frost, valves and pipes being burst.

I beg to suggest that the concrete foundation should be thoroughly overhauled and repaired, that the connecting passage with the main building should also be thoroughly treated in the same way. The outside walls should be reinforced by nailing strips outside and then nailing a good shiplap covering over which should be placed a layer of good paper and cover by siding. This would make the walls more weather-proof.

The inside plaster requires repairs also. I have not stated the position of this building any too strongly. An examination will readily verify what I have said. The repairs should be attended to during the summer of 1922.

J. R. Bunn.
Insp.
Extract from Inspector's Report on the FORT ALEXANDER BOARDING SCHOOL, February 16, 1922. 125-1-6

WATER SUPPLY.

I beg now to direct attention to the square wooden tank lined with galvanized iron. This tank requires new lining and some overhauling. The question is presented of protecting the intake pipe to prevent the recurrence of 1919 - 1920 when this intake pipe was frozen up and the water supply by this source entirely stopped. This trouble is caused by the low level of Lake Winnipeg so that during the winter the frost freezes right down to the bottom of the river where there is a shelving bank covered by water before you reach the deep channel of the river.

J. R. Bunn,

Insp.
Extract from Inspector's Report on the FORT ALEXANDER BOARDING SCHOOL. February 16, 1922.... 125-1-6.

The heating of the main school building and the laundry building is affected by steam. The boiler that is now in use for the present system is faulty. It is too small. It is done as it is too old. This lack of capacity in the boiler reduces the effectiveness of the present system and it is necessary to take steps to provide a boiler of the proper necessary capacity to provide sufficient steam for the effective work of the heating system. The present boiler was inspected and examined by an expert in the fall of 1921 in response to the direction of the Departmental Letter No. 125-1-5 dated the 14th September, 1921. The report of the expert who made the inspection is dated the 10th October, 1921, and was sent to the Department by me on the 11th of October, 1921. The information of the report is conclusive and there is not much doubt but that the boiler will have to be replaced during the coming summer of 1922 and the system overhauled. I beg to direct attention to this important matter.

J. R. Bunn,

Insp.

The floor is spruce and it is well worn and should be replaced as soon as possible. The room would be improved if painted.

This building was built in two sections at different times; the older section is about 19 years old, the newer section was built in 1913, so that this section is about 9 years old. On the whole this building is in a fair state of repair. It would, however, be very much improved if the outside was painted throughout with, at least, two coats. This is necessity and the work should not be deferred beyond the summer of 1922. The roof should be overhauled and painted. The eaves troughing should also be overhauled and repaired.

The Department has contributed towards the cost of building a suitable gasoline launch for the use of the school at Fort Alexander the sum of $1,000.00. (see Departmental letter 125-1-1 dated June 16, 1921) Of this amount about $886.00 has been expended. This outlay has provided a good hull and a good 4-cycle gasoline 12-16 h. p. engine. This leaves a balance of $114.00 of the $1,000.00. The Reverend Principal says that it will cost about $250.00 to complete the boat, that is, about $136.00 over the amount of $1,000.00 already provided. I promised that I would submit this statement for consideration. The Reverend Principal certainly got good value in the hull he had built. I think the engine was also good value.

OTTAWA, March 9th, 1922.

Sir,

With reference to your report on the inspection of the Fort Alexander boarding school, dated the 16th ultimo, referring to the repairs and alterations required to the building and heating system, also to the water system and laundry building, etc., I beg to inform you that an item is being included in the estimates for the next fiscal year to provide a new heating plant and extensive alterations to the buildings. It will depend, however, upon the action taken by Parliament at the present Session as to whether this item will be passed. We hope to be able to undertake the alterations required during the coming summer.

Regarding the extra amount required to build the gasoline launch, I beg to say that the Department will be prepared, upon receipt of properly certified vouchers, to pay the sum of $136.00 over and above the amount of $1,000 already authorized. This amount, however, can only be paid when funds are available in the new fiscal year. You may inform the Principal regarding the extra amount authorized for the building of the gasoline launch.

The advice given you regarding the proposed alterations to the building and heating plant is for your information only.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sir:

A year ago, at my request, a sum of money was voted by the Government to rebuild our stables destroyed by fire. For reasons unknown to me the construction was not made and the money was not used. Last fall, in view of the present year's estimates I applied for the following:

1o-Construction of stables and barn;
2o-" of outbuilding for boiler and purchase of latter;
3o-Painting of building;
4o-Construction of an annex to the main building.

The reasons stating the grounds for those different works are summed up in the official list of requests for our District as presented by Rev. Fr Guy O.M.I.

I understand that a certain amount of money has been voted by Parliament in the Main Estimates and I feel highly grateful for such a course. However I am rather sorry to learn that this amount will be insufficient not only to cover above requirements but even to allow the construction of the two most important items, viz: no 1 and no 2. In my opinion those intended constructions are very urgent and necessary for our school and consequently, I regret the shortage of money for I am positive that if the work is to be done in two different years the expense will be far greater on account of double freight rates and other incidentals.

If the Department finds it impossible to increase the amount of money already voted, we cannot do anything else than adopt the plan so wisely suggested by yourself, that is build an annex to the main building and remodel our fire apparatus. If this work is done coupled with the promise that the stables will be built next year and even in case of any money left over started this year we will be satisfied.

Kindly give this matter your immediate and judicious attention as I intend to leave as soon as possible for the West.

Respectfully yours,

Dear Sir,

In one of your last trips to Fort Alexander, you may have had the occasion to see the poor state of our outside root cellar: legs, poles and supports were rotten. Today, that cellar is far worse, for a part of the roof has fallen in, and the rest is ready to do the same. So everything is to be repaired, for everything is rotten.

So I ask you to be kind enough to obtain from the Indian Department the sum of $400.00 to make new walls and a new roof, for we need that cellar very badly, having no other where to put our crop of potatoes and other vegetables. I suggest to make cement walls all around, of 12 inches thick, and a cement ceiling, supported by iron columns and steel beams. Galvanised iron pipes of 2 inches, embedded in 6 inches cement, and put across the beams, will support a roof of 2 or 3 feet of ground. (Vide sketch.)

A cellar made with poles and logs as the old one will be rotten again in nine years; while an cellar in cement, like the one I am asking for, will last for ever and it will not leak.

Please, dear Mr. Bunn, write to Ottawa at the earliest convenience, for we need that cellar to put in our next crop, that is for the beginning of September.

Thanking you in advance, I remain, dear Sir

Fair Wages Clause.

All mechanics, labourers, or other persons who perform labour in the construction of the work hereby contracted for, shall be paid such wages as are generally accepted as current from time to time during the continuance of the contract for competent workmen in the district in which the work is being performed, and if there be no current rate in such district, then a fair and reasonable rate, and shall work such hours as those fixed by the custom of the trade in district where the work is carried on, or if there be no custom of the trade as respects hours in the district, then fair and reasonable hours, except for the protection of life and property, or on due cause shown to the satisfaction of the Minister of Labour. In the event of a dispute arising as to what is the current or a fair and reasonable rate of wages or what are the current hours fixed by the custom of the trade or fair and reasonable hours, it shall be determined by the Minister of Labour, whose decision shall be final. Payment may also be withheld of any moneys which would otherwise be payable to the contractor until the Minister of Labour's decision has been complied with. By the term "current wages" and the term "hours of labour fixed by the custom of the trade" in the foregoing are meant respectively the standard rates of wages and hours of labour either recognized by signed agreements between employers and workmen in the district from which the labour required is necessarily drawn or rates actually prevailing, although not necessarily recognized by signed agreements.

My dear Mr. Scott:

I have been notified that a contract for the construction of an annex to Fort Alexander School has been awarded to the Sam Brown Co. of Winnipeg.

I take the liberty of asking from the Department that Rev. Fr P. Bousquet, Principal of the School, be appointed Supervisor of the work. The reasons in favour of such a request are the following. Our experience in the past shows that in some instances, there seems to have been a certain understanding between the contractor and the supervisor, with the result that work was not properly done. I could give instances proving this statement. In other cases, the supervisor has been under the influence of liquor practically during the whole time of his inspection; consequently, the work was not done according to specifications and though the Government intended to supply the school with a first class accommodation the results were rather discouraging.

I also beg to note that as we are to administer heat and provide for the general upkeep of the buildings we have been obliged, on account of defective construction, to sustain expenses that could have been avoided if the house had been honestly built, viz: according to specifications. Let me give as examples the cases of Crowfoot School and annexes to Fort Alexander and Sandy Bay. Therefore, having in view the advantage of the Government and our own benefit, and thus obviating the lack of proper inspection, I formerly ask the Department to appoint the man who is in the best position for serving the Department's interests and assuring a really effective work.

Hoping that this request will meet with your judicious approval, I remain

Yours very truly,

Joseph [Signature]

Dear Sir:

We wish to advise you that we have taken the liberty to take a trip to Fort Alexander to make ourselves acquainted with the situation of the proposed building you intend to build there and for which we had intended to submit our figures. We also went to Selkirk to get informations as to the hauling of the material, and found out that this could not be done before the middle of Oct.

This, we believe, would mean that it would be impossible to start any work there before late in October, or early in November.

Under these conditions we believe that it would be practically impossible to make a real good job as it will be too cold at that time, specially for foundation and brick work.

We regret, not being able, or rather not take chances to start such a building after all the informations we took during our trips to Fort Alexander and Selkirk.

September 29th, 1922.

Dear Sir,

Re: Appointment of an Inspector of Construction for the Fort Alexander School Annex:

Replying to your letter of the 26th instant, with further reference to the appointment of Rev. Father P. Bousquet, as Inspector of Construction at the above mentioned school, I beg to say that the work consists in the building of an addition to the building, approximately 32' x 40' of a stone foundation, three storeys high.

The building will be built of balloon frame, sheeted inside and outside, and finished similar to existing building. The work also includes the building of a new boiler room, the installing of a new boiler, and some minor alterations to the present heating and plumbing systems in the building; the approximate cost of the work is $20,000.

Our reason for asking for this appointment is the remoteness of the situation. If we send a man there from a distance he will have to be continuously on the work at a higher rate of pay. Reverend Father Bousquet and his staff have a sufficient knowledge and experience of building to insure that the work will be performed according to the contract, and it is altogether in the interests of the Department to employ him.

Yours very truly,

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir,

In making excavation for new sewer, we have discovered the old cesspool, which is constructed of wood, has fallen in. The wood, 20 years old, is completely rotten and impossible to repair.

The only way to rectify same is to build a new manhole. There will be sufficient bricks from old boilers, and I can supply some to make one.

I have taken the matter up with the contractor; and he believes that the sum of three hundred and fifty dollars will cover all the expenses.

We cannot wait for something better; we have to build a man hole, for we cannot do without any. So I beg to ask you authority to go ahead and build one.

I suggest to make a manhole 4 ft. 6 x 4 ft. 6 going about 3 ft. lower than the sewer pipe. So that manhole will be about 9 ft. deep, and covered by an iron trap.

Please wire your answer by the telegraph station of Lac du Bonnet, and believe me, dear Sir,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Reference to Mr. McKenzie's letter,
File No. RGO-G., October 26th, concerning fixtures to our
electric plant.

I have been enquiring about prices of different firms, but I could not have good satisfaction.
Most of the firms have no catalogues. Two only have sent one: Eaton's and J.H. Ashdown Co. from Winnipeg.
Eaton's Co. has only one page of fixtures, but all his fixtures are wired and ready for installing, glass shades included.

J.H. Ashdown has perhaps more fixtures in his catalogue, but they include only wiring and sockets, no shades and no lamps.

I cannot wait any longer to get more information from firms; the electrician is to be here next week for his work, and we must have the fixtures here if we want them installed by him. So I sent you Eaton's and Ashdown's catalogues, marking on them what we need.

Dear Sir,

I have your letter number and date as quoted above, also the enclosures, the same being the Invoice of certain material used in building the Root House at Fort Alexander School, and the Abstract of Tenders therefore.

I was away up Lake Winnipeg and asked Father Bousquet to purchase the materials in question, getting competitive prices when he did so, and awarding the order to the best price, value & quality being a factor in deciding the proper place to put the order.

I have looked into the matter of purchasing iron pipe and iron rails required. I find that the material furnished by The Standard Plumbing Co. was all cut and made ready to be placed in work, so that there was no waste, the rails supplied being railway steel rails as against cast iron. In view of these facts I think that the materials bought were much better value, and in addition, were prepared for the use they were intended for so that there was no waste. For these reasons I think the Reverend Principal placed the order where he got the best and most suitably prepared material. I also understand that The Standard Plumbing Co. furnished a smaller and stiffer piping, so that there were more strands in the base of the concrete work, which of course was an improvement. The difference in the prices quoted is more than overcome by the suitability of the material furnished for the slightly higher price.

I beg to recommend the action of the Reverend Father in securing the best value.

I hope the explanation will clear up this matter.

your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

On the 19th of December last, I was calling your attention to the fact that some improvements should be made in the boiler room of our School. I suggested to install ceiling joist forming air space between roof and ceiling, and board underneath joist, and strap lath with metal lath and plaster with asbestos. But I did not receive any answer yet; but I beg to inform you, Dear Sir, that something has to be done without delay if we do not want to be obliged to fix again that same roof, next spring. Being in direct contact, the heat of furnaces melts the snow on the top of the roof and makes a heap of ice all around on the edge, one foot high. The eaves troughs of that same roof are full of ice, now, and I am sure that they have been broken already and bursted. The concrete walls are all wet, and will be spoiled and cracked by frost. We have been chopping that ice on
the roof of the boiler room, and we found the edges already spoiled in many places by frost raising boards, shingles and everything.

The Contractor's men are working still, and will work about one month more. I hope you will take occasion of their presence to have everything fixed right.

I remain, Sir,

Yours respectfully.

Dear Secretary,

I beg to lay before you, my claim for payment for painting done at "the Fort Alexander Indian School."

On January 1st, this year, I, the undersigned was approached by Mr. Burkell with a proposition of painting at the Fort Alexander School at the rate of six cents per square ft.

Mr. Burkell, whom I understood was the "foreman" for the J. Brown Co General Contractors, represented the painting required to be a cheap line of straightforward work, and that the price was set by your Department at Ottawa. Also, that I was to have a helper provided in all work required of me.

Under these conditions, I accompanied Mr. Burkell back to Fort Alexander, and commenced work. Two, or three days later, I protested to Mr. Burkell that the work was not as was represented to me, and
that she was not providing the helper as promised. Whereupon Mr. Burkel promised to make arrangements with Mr. Brown, to cover my board and room bill, in addition to my pay of six cents per sq. yd. for all straight work, and that all trimmings, pipes, and radiators, were to be considered as extra work, and paid for by the hour.

Mr. Brown was expected at any time, but did not actually appear until the 23rd of Jan.

Mr. Brown evaded me, although his short stay, and upon leaving refused to come to any reasonable terms.

He offered me one hundred and fifty dollars to finish up the work which I did not accept, but I did agree to finish the convent chapel then in hand, and urgently required, pending results of direct correspondence between Mr. Brown, and myself.

A week later, having finished the chapel, I proceeded to Winnipeg to interview Mr. Brown.

Now the outcome of this interview is that Mr. Brown not only refuses to make any fair or reasonable terms with me, but also refuses to pay me for any of my work executed.

My reason for refusing Mr. Brown's
offer of One hundred and fifty dollars, is in view of the fact that it will require at least eight weeks for one man to complete the work from start to finish, while he must pay Ten dollars and fifty cents per week for his Board and Room, the only rate existing at Fort Alexander.

Also it seems that I cannot accept such an offer without the approval of your Department and without it being in direct violation of the "sub-letting" clause, provided in the specifications of the General Contract.

In view of the above dispute will you consider my claim for all work done, it being Two hundred and thirty-six (236) hours at eighty cents per hour, this being the Winnipeg rate as set by the "Fair Wage Commission" of 1922.

Should you decide that this is a matter for the attention of the Ministry of Labour, will you kindly forward this letter to that Department without delay, and as I have been at considerable expense this unfortunate affair has placed me in financial difficulties.

Trusting that this claim set forth above will receive your consideration

I am yours Very Truly,

Sir,

On the 3rd February last, I addressed you with reference to a request for some assistance that the Reverend Principal of Fort Alexander Indian Boarding School was asking for towards defraying the cost of some benches, tables and cupboards that are necessary for the dormitories of the pupils of the school.

I explained that I made inquiry into this matter when I was at Fort Alexander at the end of January last, and I found that the Reverend Principal had found that the cost of these articles would run up to approximately $500.00, as he had partially constructed some of the cupboards.

The assistance asked for is a grant of $250.00 towards the payment of the total cost.

I was satisfied that the request was a reasonable one and I recommended it for favorable consideration.

Father Bousquet called on me last evening and asked what had been done. I told him that I had not received a reply. May I ask respectfully what is the intention of the Department in this regard?

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir,

Answer to your letter No. 125-1-5, from
the 9th of March.... Re misunderstanding between Mr. Luke,
painter, and Mr. Brown, contractor.

The case of Mr. Luke is a little hard
to judge, for there is no written contract, but directly made
between him and Mr. Brown; but it seems evident that Mr. Brown
contractor, and Mr. Burkell, the foreman and father-in-law of
Mr. Brown, have been working in concert from the beginning,
wishing to feel Mr. Luke for the painting work.

Mr. Burkell, knowing Mr. Luke, wrote to him
asking to tender on the job. Mr. Luke sent to him the following tender:

To Mr. Burkell, foreman of construction
Fort Alexander Indian School.

Dear Sir,

I the undersigned, do hereby tender
for the painting to be done at the Fort Alexander Indian
School, at the rate of 6 cents by Sq. yard, there not be less
than nine hundred and ninety Sq. yards, two coat work.
Transportation to be provided from Winnipeg.

(Copy was supplied by Mr. Luke.)

This tender was not at the time and never has been signed by Mr. Burkell, neither by Mr. Brown. Even Mr. Sam Brown says that Mr. Burkell never had authority to engage him. Although it is Mr. Burkell who wrote to Mr. Luke and paid his fare to come from Winnipeg to Fort Alexander, how to explain it?

On the way to Fort Alexander, Mr. Burkell promised an helper to Mr. Luke that he never got. Why should Mr. Burkell be allowed to tell something untrue if he was not allowed to engage a man?

If Mr. Burkell was not representing Mr. Sam Brown in dealing with Mr. Luke, why was his word accepted as a truth, for being in Winnipeg, he wickedly misrepresent the work done by Mr. Luke, saying it was not done right? According to him and Mr. Brown, he was too slow on the job. On that report of Mr. Burkell, Luke was put out of the way by Mr. Brown. If Mr. Burkell was not his intermediate why did Mr. Brown accept his wicked report?

According to me, the work of Mr. Luke was superior to the work of the two other painters that have been here in succession to finish the inside painting. I have proved it to Mr. Brown already.

II.

Now, being in Fort Alexander, Mr. Burkell sent
3.

Mr. Luke to paint windows, ceilings, dear frames, etc... So he had very little straight work; and by the fact a very little chance to make money.

111.

Some time ago, I had a talk with Mr. Brown about his misunderstanding with Mr. Luke. He told me he was ready to pay him 7 cents by Sq.yard if the painter was willing to accept his offer.

I drove then to Mr. Luke's and I explained the words of Mr. Brown. He refused plainly Mr. Brown's offers for many reasons that I asked him to summarize. I copy them from the letter he wrote to me.

1st. reason.

"In spite of, and after the maze of piping, the numerous window sash, and frames, deers, picture mouldings, and W joints, there only remains the ceilings.

"Mr. Brown offers me in settlement at a rate which is two cents per yard below that which prevails for the cheapest line of straight wall work."

2nd. reason.

The type of work as mentioned above is never measured on a Sq.yard basis in the trade, and it would be a gross injustice to be forced to accept such a scandalous settlement.

3rd. reason.

I beg to state, that Mr. Brown's motives had have been honest, and above board, he would glad ly have drawn an agreement constituted on a basis of his
present and latest offer. Mr. Brown failed to do this as probably such an agreement would have had the approval of the Department of Indian Affairs, or because as he net I was supplying all Materials, I was within the category of a Subcontractor, according to the specifications of the General Contract.

"In pressing my claim, I beg to bring to your notice, says Mr. Luke, that I am making a liberal concession in only demanding 'the wage of a journeyman painter,' instead of a 'price of a contractor,' and I am covering my own expenses."

Conclusion.

Mr. Luke is asking 80 cts. per hour for the whole time he has been working here at Fort Alexander, that is 248 hours. So his wages would be $198.40. As far as I know, Mr. Luke got already from Mr. Brown the sum of $68.90.

I have been exposing the case as clearly as I could. It is to you new to give a decision; and I am sure it will be the right one.

I remain, dear Sir,

Yours truly,

Dear Sir,

Response to your letter, No. 125-1-5,
dated from the 9th of March, asking information about the sum of $1200.00 charged by Mr. Brown, contractor, for building in of boiler in new laundry, and placing of drying machinery.

Mr. Brown has supplied me the details for that sum. You will find, herewith enclosed, copy of his figures.

In his information, Mr. Brown is mentioning some painting that was done. This requires a few words of explanation from my part.

As plastered walls in old building were painted, and owing to so much plaster that had fallen off and had to be replastered, it left the work in a deplorable condition without repainting more than the prepared patch. Also in many places such as the junction of old corridors with new, it was impossible to make the building presentable without painting a part of the walls in old corridors.
to correspond with new parts. It has been the same in the private room located between the two girls dormitories, in the sewing room, and staff dining room. All these rooms were formed of an old and of a new part; and to make them uniform, we had to paint them all over. Mr. Brown's figures are perhaps a little exaggerated; but I consider the painting was absolutely necessary, and we have not done anything that Government could reprove.

Now what could be the cost of painting done by Mr. Brown? According to him, it would be about $358.00.

According to me $150.00 should cover plenty the expenses, for in his measurements is counting what he had to paint by contract (I mean to paint patches he had to replaster, in old building.) and what he was not perhaps exactly obliged to paint. Anyway he deserves $150.00, for he has given a good value for that item.

Hoping you will find my report satisfactory

I remain, Dear Sir,

Yours respectfully,

Dear Sir,

Specifications concerning the addition to be made at our School House call for a wooden ladder and hinge trap doors for fire escape on the girl's side. I beg to make remark fire escapes of that kind have many inconveniences. The greatest of all is to give an easy way to climb up to visit the girls in dormitories. I have an objection also to the hinge traps: in winter time, being frozen and covered with snow, these traps could not be opened quick enough in case of hurry.

Here is what I propose to do: I propose an iron pipe of 3 inch diameter for fire escape, and a trap of form of crate, opening in centre, as per sketch. A trap of that kind will hold the snow and it will be easy to open in case of fire. Nobody could climb up to visit the girls in using the 3" pipe. Besides that experience proves that children, even girls, will slide...
down quicker on a pipe than they can do in a ladder.

Mr. Brown is ready to have iron crates made and put in place with the 3" pipe for the sum of $90.00 ninety dollars. I beg to call to your attention that it will require about 40 ft of 3" pipe, and flanges and straps to hold them. It will require also 2 double crate traps, which will cost about $25.00 per set.

I consider the above fire escape as necessary, and I don't like at all, for the mentioned reasons, the wooden ladders. (I had trouble already with that kind of fire escape.) Therefore I ask with instance and entreat the Indian Department to be so good to grant my request for the security of our school children.

I remain, Dear Sir,

Yours respectfully.

[Signature]

Principal & Inspector.

P.S. As they are working at the verandahs where are to be the fire escapes, I beg to ask an answer at the earliest convenience.

Ottawa, May 8, 1923.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the first instant, enclosing a statement from the principal of the Fort Alexander Boarding School as to the number of desks required. It is noted that 45 double desks of various sizes and 8 rears are requested. This would provide seating accommodation for 106 pupils, i.e., 2 pupils per desk.

The per capita grant allowed this school is for 76 pupils. As there are no doubt, some of the old desks on hand, which are in good condition, it is not understood why the principal asks for the above mentioned number. Please refer this matter again to the principal. He should state the type of desk at present in the school and the number, if any, which could be continued in use, and he should revise the list of his requirements.

After taking into account the number of serviceable desks at present in the school, we would not be prepared to provide further seating accommodation for any number in excess of the number of grant-earning pupils allowed. As soon as we have this additional information, we will be prepared to consider the principal's request for supplying these desks, also the teacher's desk and chair.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

Dear Sir,

The addition made to our School, about 12 years ago, was so poorly painted that today we consider that one coat of paint, as required by the actual contract of Mr. S. Brown, will not be sufficient to make a decent job. The paint has peeled off, leaving the lumber bare and nearly black. One coat only will not sufficient to make an uniform painting. Dear Sir:

I have just learned that Mr. Sam. Brown of Winnipeg has obtained the contract to build our stable at Fort Alexandre. I regret this very much and I protest once more against this decision from the Department. I have several reasons for this, and here are the principal ones.

1ST: Mr. Brown leaves the work dragging. It is already ten months since the addition to our school was started, and it is not yet complete. I cannot even say when he will finish it; God knows how he made us suffer during last Winter by employing only Indians to do 30% of the work. They work at a lower price it is true; but very badly and very slowly.

2ND: Mr. Brown tries to make money by every means good or bad. If he is not continually watched, he loses no chance to deceive or to make his men cheat.

3RD: The Indian Department should have noticed that in his last undertaking he exaggerated the price for extras. Mr. Brown proposes to do the same thing for the next one. It is on that he expects to make money. There will be extras inevitably. I foresee some already. V.C. A stable with three thicknesses of walls and a floor without a ceiling for the garret is insufficiently warm for our cold climate of the N.W., especially when in this stable there will constantly be water in the water pipes; no light is indicated on the plan to be placed in the garret, some will be needed, here are as many extras on which Mr. Brown will jump and make money.

My protest may not be of great use, I believe, if the contract is already given to this Mr. Brown, but I wish to ask the Department to have the work hurried and to fix a date on which the stable must be completely finished. We need our stable for the end of September, so far Mr. Brown has not shown up. I completely ignore if he thinks at all of gathering the material for building. He told one of his confidential friends that he had five months ahead of him to erect this building. With which calculations he will deliver the stable only at Christmas time.

Again I wish to ask the Government to have the work started at once so that our stable be completed for the middle of September.

Believe me, Sir, Yours respectfully,

P. Bousquet, O.M.I.

Dear Sir,

I have received your estimated No. 197 173 4, dated from the 27th last, where you are telling me you did not receive an answer to different questions you made some time ago about class desks and chairs that were required for the Indian Boarding School at Fort Alexander. I am very sorry you did not get them; but I beg to say that I sent them to Mr. Bunn, our Inspector, who transmitted to me your letter, and not Mr. Latulippe as marked in your last note to me. Even he promised me to make a report after he had seen the poor state of our old desks. Probably Mr. Bunn has been taking some holidays or he has been overwhelmed with work so much that he could not put his plan in execution.

I beg to copy a part of the letter I was writing him: "It is very kind indeed from the part of the Indian Department to offer spontaneously single desks instead of double ones asked for, the single ones..."
being far dearer, and I have to testify my gratitude for it; but since we are limited by the space in our class rooms, I believe to be preferable to ask for double desks with divided seat, for the two class rooms. I beg to make you remark that in the senior class, the number of the desks has to be equal to the number of boarders,-for very often, V.G. for Sunday school, general advances, evening studies, etc... the whole bunch of children has to come into that room. We have 77 children presently on the pay rolls; and since our school has been enlarged, we can receive far more boarders, and it will be easy to get about 100."

I believe the informations I was giving Mr. Bunn, some time ago, will satisfy the Indian Department. I must add that Mr. Bunn, seeing the old desks we have, said that none of them was decent.

Thanking you, dear Sir, for the great interest you give to the Indian Education in general, and to our School in particular, I hope you will give orders immediately to send us the desks required to replace the 22 years old desks we have in class now.

Dear Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your telegram of the 28th inst., refusing to authorize extra lights and switches required by my letter of the 15th, for our new barn; and I dare to insist on having them as I consider them an absolute necessity. I am persuaded, dear Sir, when knowing my reasons you will not refuse them longer.

1st---You refuse to authorize lights in the loft of our barn, where they are necessary, none being provided for in specifications and plan. Even during the day, without electric lights, we couldn't do any work in the loft, lighted only by two small windows located at each end of the barn 108 ft. long. How could we manage in winter nights, when feeding cattle ??? I believe I am right in applying for some lamps.

2nd---You also refuse switches for the inside of stables, -(No additional lamps having been asked
for) - I consider it be necessary to have them, for short cord lamps have to be used to keep the bulbs out of danger of breakage, in both cow and horse stables. Here are the reasons:

A/—In the center alley, no drop lamps can be used, for they would be in the way of the litter carriers and would broken by boys when cleaning the stables.

B/—In feeding alleys, drop lamps would be more exposed yet to the long fork handles of the boys feeding the cattle. Every day, we would have some Tungsten lamps to replace.

Knowing the necessity to have the lamps hung close to the ceiling, you understand, dear Sir, that switches are also necessary at different places shown in the sketch sent to you with my last letter. Plan of stable shows only 3 switches: they are not enough to command all the high lamps, and our small electric generator will not allow us to burn them all at once. If you cannot allow switches asked for, I cannot see how to get a good light in the stables and at the same time to prevent an incessant breakage of lamps.

I would be very obliged to you, dear Sir, in wiring at once your favorable answer by Victoria Beach in care of Thompson Bros.

I remain, dear Sir, Yours respectfully.

I beg to ask authorisation to put some lumber on the concrete floor between the stalls where the cattle will have to lay down in our new barn. Dear Sir:

Re. our conversation in regard to Swing pole for barn at Ft. Alexander
The specifications do not call for a swing pole. A swing pole is
not part and parcel of a Litter Carrier Outfit unless specially
called for. The only references to a Swing Pole are the two items
in the note on page 21. Here one swing pole attachment and one
swinging track hinge are specified. This note also states "See
Carpenter's specifications for supports to outside construction
for distance of fifty feet".

When compiling our estimates we did not pay any attention to this
as nothing of our line was called for except the track and hangers,
and we would have nothing to do with the wood work. On checking
back we cannot find any reference an Carpenter's specifications
re outside extension. No swing pole of any length was included in
our estimates or in your order to us.

Further a fifty foot swing pole could not, with safety, be hung with
guy rods from the end of the barn. It would unquestionably pull the
whole end out of the barn.

In order to give proper and adequate service, we would suggest that
you have the department provide for the erection of a tripod the
same as illustrated on page 267 of our Barn Book. This tripods can
be erected of two stout poles twenty feet from the barn. Between
the barn and the tripod the track can be hung on a timber, say 6x8"
fastened to the barn at one end and to a cross piece on the tripod
at the other. Then a thirty foot steel swing pole could be hung
from this tripod. This pole can be swung from side to side quite
freely and will provide for ample space for depositing the manure a
proper distance from the barn.

This swing pole with all attachments will cost you $60.00. This
will entail no strain on the barn and for this little extra, the
department would have a permanent and very serviceable equipment
for handling the manure outside the barn.

Over
Now in regard to the discrepancies in the measurements for the steel cow stalls and the place where you have placed the Supporting Columns, beg to advise that we have taken the measurements for the width of the stalls as specified on the plan. The figures there state that the stalls are to be 3ft 6inches wide. We made them up this width taking the measurements from centre to centre. In placing your supporting columns, you have apparently taken centre to centre measurements but this apparently does not harmonize with the figures given. We feel that we were justified in taking the figures as shown and working on centre to centre measurements, as the figures shown on the cross section measurements work out exactly centre to centre in making up the width of the barn.

To add the necessary material and send a man down to do the necessary extra work needed to put the manger partitions in their proper place is an expenditure that we should not be called upon to assume. The prices charged for material supplied do not provide for this and the mistake has not been occasioned by any error of ours. It has been caused by the figures shown and the scale measurements not agreeing. This extra cost will be about $45.00.

Doubtless when you place these situations before the department you will have no difficulty in getting a proper allowance made.

Yours truly,

BEATTY BROS. LIMITED

Dear Sir,

I am taking the liberty to ask you the favor to supply us with a tractor, a double furrow plow and a threshing machine with blower. During twenty years we had a small outfit for threshing, but it was so broken and inadequate with the size of our farm that I sold it last Fall, for a very small sum. So we have to get a new and larger one for next spring; but it should be strong enough to push the straw directly into the loft of our new barn. A machine of that kind will exempt us from much work and useless expenses.

We need also a tractor which will be used for cutting wood, threshing, and chiefly for plowing in Summer. At the present time we cannot control bad weeds by means of producing a rotation of crops. In spite of our efforts, sow thistles, wild oats and other bad weeds are prevalent in our lands; and this is caused by the freedom to grow the Indians give those weeds.
on the Reserve, -(We are included in the Indian Reserve.)- Summer ploughing will be the only mean to destroy them; but unfortunately we cannot do it with horses, because, in June, July and August, mosquitos and ox flies are innumerable in Fort Alexander. Having a tractor we could plough at any time in spite of their nuisance. We could use it also for cutting kitchen wood and threshing our crops.

Hoping that you will accept favorably my request in granting what I ask you,

I am taking the liberty to ask you another favor, that is to provide us with a tractor, two furrow-plows and a threshing-machine with blower. Our old threshing machine of twenty years and our fifteen year old gas-engine were unable to do our farm work any more. The only means of destroying them is the summer-furrow, and this cannot be done with horses; the reason is that the flies are too bad in the summer, here in Fort Alexander. That is the main reason why I wish to have a tractor; the other reason is that we need a threshing machine and we have no engine to run it: The tractor would serve the purpose.

Sir:

Herewith I beg to enclose a letter that I received from the Reverend Father Bousquet, O.M.I., Principal of the Indian Residential School at Fort Alexander.

The retention was a mistake. I find that the Reverend Father sent me both copies; they were closely pinned together, and I did not observe this.

The Reverend Principal fully explains himself and what he seeks very clearly.

Re Threshing Machine.

He explains with reference to this machine he indicates that he wants a machine with a blower, and he gives the reason why he would like to get such a machine. I beg to concur with him and to say that his ideas are right to enable economy in handling his straw and doing the work to the best advantage.

Re The tractor.

The Reverend Principal indicates the uses to which he can put this machine, and his arguments are all fair and reasonable. The most important feature in my judgement is that he will be able to do some summer fallowing. Owing to the location, it is almost impossible to use horses, owing to the presence in myriads of Mosquitoes, Black Flies, Bull-dog Flies and other pests that drive the poor animals wild and make them difficult to control if summer-fallowing is attempted. I know that the noxious weeds that he mentions flourish, and he is anxious to destroy these if he can.

Re 2 Furrow Plow.

The Reverend has mentioned this to me, and he would like to get a machine of this sort to be operated by the Tractor in his summer-fallowing work.

I have told the Rev'd Principal that I would submit this letter.
letter of his for the consideration of the Department. He would like to know as soon as possible if he can expect a favorable reply about the Machinery that I have mentioned, and which his letter also makes mention off.

He has suggested that he would make the purchases of this machinery, if he was assured that he could expect a refund of the purchase price. I told him I would mention this suggestion of his, but that I felt that the Department would not be influenced in their decision, as there was a certain procedure in making such purchases that regulated all such business.

The weather up here has been very mild, it is my opinion that a Spring break-up is not closely at hand. The ice on Lake Winnipeg is about 3 feet or over in thickness and is still solid and sound. The Principal expected to transport this machinery over the ice from Victoria Beach, if he got it, and I am convinced that the ice can be safely count on up to the 20th instant. Please wire if necessary the decision about this.

There is no doubt but that the Farming work of the Indian Boarding School at Fort Alexander has been conducted along successful lines by the management of the school, and I beg to suggest that this activity deserves all the assistance that can be fairly given to help to maintain continued successful operation, and there is little doubt but that the machinery now asked for will give this assistance in a manner that will be most beneficial.

The school farm has been cut off heavy bush land and is now about 90 acres. This whole area is worked and the results assist the successful operation of the school work and affords a means of teaching the boys in this important line of work.

The Reverend Principal is aggressive in his methods, and wishes to get this valuable assistance from the Department to enable him to achieve a fuller measure of success.

Dear Sir:

As per your instructions I went to Fort Alexander Indian Boarding School with an expert mechanic, to locate the trouble in their Water and Lighting Plant System.

We found the Gas Engine in a very bad condition.

Engine Trouble:
First: The engine is set on no concrete foundation, but bolted only on a wooden floor with a cellar underneath without being braced. The constant vibration of the engine which has a weight of 1700 pounds has worn out several parts of the engine:
Ash Pot, Auxiliary Air Valve, Nut, Springs, Vapopizer, Governor Yoke, Ignitor Pawl Carrier, Magneto and Ignitor Points, Loose Bearings, Cam, Roller and a Leaking Fuel Tank.

Generator: Changing pulley on generator to get proper speed - 1200 R.P.M. and adjusting Generator Brushes.

Batteries:
These were in a very bad condition, not being properly charged to their maximum capacity; lead substance from the negative and positive plates was accumulated at the bottom of batteries to a point of making a short circuit to the batteries. Jars were opened and cleaned and put in a satisfactory condition.

The Machinist in charge understands now, the operation of the Electric Plant System and is going to see that everything is kept O.K. Will install a foundation for the engine and they are also going to change the drive pulley for the pump so as to drive the pump at 35 to 40 R.P.M. which should be the proper speed and also use the loose pulley when not pumping water.
R. J. Bunn, Esq.,

We were compelled to make a second trip to get the proper repairs, and feel now that we have given you our best attention that your Water and Lighting Plant System is in good working order.

We are enclosing our statement of repairs, time and expense, including the two trips to Fort Alexander.

Hoping you find this satisfactory,

In answer to your inquiry re my opinion about your Electric Plant, I beg to say that, as far as I know, the chief source of trouble is, that the engine you have has not, and as a matter of fact never had enough power for the work it has to do.
