Dear Sir,

In five years, we have spent about 4000 dollars (About 800 dollars every year) in buying kerosene to run the electric plant of our School. Everybody admits that it is enormous; but it seems that we do not spend kerosene enough, for two years ago, we had to change the plates of our batteries, and today, again, they are in a very bad shape and will have to be renewed before next winter.

In truth I do not know what to do to reduce those heavy expenses. Experts in electricity from Winnipeg and two very good electrician Brothers of the Congregation of the Oblate Fathers agree to say after the inspection of our Plant, that our engine is too weak for the work it has to do. Our engine is a 9 H.P. and our Dynamo develops 110 volts. Now experts in electrical work declare that 10 volts require 1 h.p.. If it is so
the engine was short from the beginning of 2 H.P.; and today being worn, it is far worse.

I take the liberty, dear Sir, to enclose herewith a letter of Brother Eugene Gauthier, concerning this matter. He has been discussing the question with Mr. Orr, in Ottawa, last Spring. So they know what they were talking about; and I will suggest to go according to their plans and to buy a new engine. It will be necessary also to fix our batteries, for the plates seem to be very weak. Those batteries have been supplied by the Globelite Co. from Winnipeg.

Mr. Russel Ferrier, Superintendent of Ind. Education, was here a few days ago. He had occasion to remark the reddish color and the weakness of our light. He understands the necessity to do something to improve the situation.

I remain, Sir,

respectfully yours.

Dear Mr Scott:

Rev. Fr Bousquet O.M.I., Principal of Fort Alexander Indian Boarding School, seems at a loss over some painting to be done at his school during this present fiscal year. I understand that an amount is included in the estimates to that effect.

In the course of June, he received the visit of Inspector Christianson in connection with this matter. This gentleman arrived at 10:30 hrs P.M. and insisted upon an immediate inspection of the interior of the building. On account of the late hour, Rev. Fr Bousquet refused to comply with his wishes as the sisters and children were in bed. Finally, Mr Christianson contented himself, that evening, with measuring the outside of the building and part of the interior. Since his visit, nothing having been heard from Regina, Rev. Fr Bousquet wired or wrote Commissioner Graham who answered that the matter was in the hands of the Department at Ottawa. Then a wire from the Department, dated July 29th, stating that Commissioner Graham had been authorized to arrange for the said painting, has rather puzzled the Rev. Principal. Moreover, the Department's wire refers to the painting of only the exterior of the main building. Rev. Fr Bousquet requests me to respectfully submit to you the fact that pursuant to his contract for the annex of the school, Contractor Brown put three coats of paint on the exterior and interior of the annex and two coats on the exterior of the main building. Therefore the painting of the exterior of the main building (with the exception of the roof) is not a necessity and Rev. Fr Bousquet never asked for it.

Rev. Fr Bousquet's request was for the painting of the roof of the main building, interior of the latter, except the annex, and of the outbuildings as follows: laundry, 2 coats; icehouse, 3 coats; granaries(2), 1 coat; henhouse,
2 coats; implement shed, 3 coats; shop, 1 coat.

Do you not think, Mr Scott, that the policy of asking Commissioner Graham to look after a small work to be undertaken in Manitoba is quite an expensive proposition (trips of the inspector from Regina and other items), a source of unnecessary delay without, in the end, the satisfaction of excellent work?

At the present juncture, I would suggest that Rev Fr Bousquet confer with Inspector Bunn, giving him all details, measurements, etc and that Mr Bunn be given authority to advertise for tenders for paint only. Then, Rev. Fr Bousquet could secure at a reasonable salary a painter or painters to do the work without undue delay and in an efficient manner.

I hope that you will give consideration to this matter and as Rev. Fr Bousquet is away from communications I would welcome a wire Tuesday at my Winnipeg address in order that I may get in touch with him as soon as possible.

Yours very truly,

Joseph [signature]

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

On June 30th and July 1st I visited the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School in company with the Rev. Father Plourde of the Oblate Provincial office, St. Boniface, Man. I was impressed by the splendid site, five miles from the south end of Winnipeg. The grounds were neat, but required proper fencing. The main building was well kept, but the roof and the interior of the old wing require painting. Several outbuildings also should be painted. A boat house for a 32 ft. launch is required. The barn which the Department lately erected and the implement shed erected by the principal complete the outbuildings required.

The farm is inadequate and I advised the Rev. Father Bousquet, the Principal, to make a report when the institution was prepared to do some clearing and an effort to secure more land from the reserve would be made. The garden and pasturage were very good, but field crops are inadequate.

Mechanical plant, house equipment, etc., is in good condition, with the exception of the light generating unit. I advised the principal to correspond with the Department in this connection and I see his letter is already on file. Eventually a washer and an extractor should be provided for the laundry.

I believe a mistake was made when the addition to the building was erected. There are two storeys in the addition, whereas in the main building there are three, the roof over the whole being the same level. It might be possible, without great expense, to turn the addition into a three story structure, thus providing two dormitories and a classroom below.

I purpose purchasing two sewing machines, which are urgently required, and sending authority to the agent to secure 125 ft. of rope, suitable for girls' swings.

I learned that Inspector Christianson visited the school a few weeks before I did, for the purpose of determining what painting should be undertaken. He arrived in the late evening after dark and left about 2 hours afterwards.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, No.125-1-5, confirming your Night Letter to me of the same date, also informing me that it had been brought to your attention that the roof of the main building of the Fort Alexander School should be painted, and asking me to make enquiries in this connection.

In reply I beg to say that Mr. Inspector Christianson, who is here today, informs me that the roof of this building is in good repair and does not require re-painting. I think this information is correct and I am prepared to act on the Inspector's advice in this matter.

You state that you have found and examined my letter #202-9 of the 23rd of June and notice that I have dealt with three distinct subjects in this communication, and point out that I must know that it is the rule of the Department to deal with only one subject in a letter, and that failure to do this results in confusion on the files. I would assume from these remarks that my letter to you, which dealt with such an important matter, involving the expenditure of a couple of thousands of dollars, was lost sight of simply because I had erred in dealing with more than one subject in one letter.

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
If you will refer to my files for the last four years you will see that it has been the practice, and, I believe, accepted by you as correct, to deal with all matters brought out by the Inspector in a covering letter. I am quite aware that it is necessary for me when making an application for authority, to deal with only one subject in one letter, but I certainly did not know that I was to write five or six letters accompanying a report, and I cannot believe that it is your wish that I should do this. I have referred to my files here and find that you have done precisely the same thing, in every case when acknowledging reports you have dealt with four or five subjects in the same letter. Extracts are made from these letters when received and placed on the respective files, so that I do not think I can be found fault with if you yourself follow the same practice, which I believe is the correct one.

As a matter of fact the delay in getting this work at the Fort Alexander School started is not attributable to carelessness in this office. It seems to me that even though you had lost sight of my letter on the subject, you should have known that there was some good reason for not starting the work and it was only fair that you should have ascertained this before wiring me as you did.

I suppose that someone came into your office complaining that the work had not been started, or that you received a letter to that effect and you decided to take the work out of my hands. We are not going to get very far in dealing with Departmental business in this way.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th inst. regarding the painting required at Fort Alexander Residential School.

In reply I beg to say that I am not able to tell how many gallons or pounds of paint are required for the work, not being an expert in painting; but I believe by telephone you can easily obtain from professional painters the necessary information. I beg to give you here the sizes in square feet of each building that requires paint.

To be painted in white with grey trimming:
- Old Laundry: 2475 Sq.Ft. 2 coats
- Icehouse: 1136 " 3 "
- Latrines (boys & girls): 1800 3
- Machine Shop: 1648 2
- One Granary: 880 2

Total: 7929 Square feet

To be painted in red with white trimmings:
- Henhouse: 870 Sq.Ft. 2 coats
- One Grainery: 870 2 "
- Machinery Shed: 1920 3 "

Please do not send cheap paint, neither already mixed paint. The desire of the Department in Ottawa is to supply the best material, for lasting longer, the best is always the cheapest. So I beg to ask you pure white lead and pure linseed oil; we will make the mixtures ourselves. Please supply also superior red barn paint.

In your letter, dear Sir, you suggest me to paint the inside of the school building. I beg to say, it is my opinion, it seems to be a misunderstanding between your office and Ottawa. The Indian Department in Ottawa was writing me a couple weeks ago saying that the whole amount of money granted in the estimates was only for the outside painting; and, you, with the same sum you want me to paint everything, inside and outside. How to explain this discrepancy?

Anyway it is too late now to talk of painting the inside of our school, for the children are back from holidays. How to paint in fact the dormitories, dining rooms, class rooms and recreation room when the children are present? Passages and private rooms could be done now.

Before to start painting, I want to be sure to have a reasonable salary for painter or painters. In this time of the year, I have plenty work on the farm for my few biggest boys and for my two men of the staff; I cannot put them on painting. So I will be obliged to get somebody else to do it, and to pay from three to four dollars a day.

I hope you will give consideration to this matter, and you will give me satisfaction. More delay will make more difficult our painting work.

I remain, Sir,

Yours respectfully,

P. Bousquet.

P.S. Paint should be addressed to Mile 70, Victoria Beach line, c/o Thomson. As we go there occasionally only, please let us know the soonest possible when ordering it. We have mail only once a week.

Sir:

I have received your letter of the 12th inst., telling me to ask Mr. Bunn to supply what I need in red paint. I wrote to him as soon as I got your letter; but the paint is yet to come.

The wishes of the Indian Department and mine would have been to paint the roof of our School if possible; but in sending no material to do the work, naturally you force us to wait until next spring. To console me you say in your letter: "I think it will be in the interest of all concerned to do so". Perhaps I don't catch the whole meaning of your sentence but I confess that I find it strange.

Anyway there is some work to be done on the roof this year, (leakages and repairs of different kind.) I was expecting to have it done at the time of painting, using the same ladders and scaffolds; it would have been easy to do it. Now painting being delayed, it will be necessary to spend about 20 dollars to make those repairs; who is to support those expenses?

It seems to me, dear Sir, you have adopted the method to do all what you can to delay the painting of our School; and the reasons I have to think so are coming from different facts.

1. Having authority since last June to arrange for the carrying out of the painting you sent the paint in the beginning of September only.

2. Instead of 5 or 6 brushes to rush the work you have sent only two.

3. Instead of ordering directly the red paint through Mr. Bunn you write me to ask Mr. Bunn to order it. So we lose time in waiting after paint that we didn't get yet.

4. The painting of the roof is delayed now up to next spring, expecting perhaps if possible to put it off till doomsday.

When a person is willing to do some work, it goes at it and sticks to it until finished. It does not seem to be the case for our painting. The more delay they can put in it the better it is.

I remain, Sir,

Yours respectfully,

(Sgd.) P. Bousquet, O.M.I.

Dear Sir,

Knowing by experience your kindness and your desire to help as much as you can the Indian Schools, I take the liberty to ask you two new favors for our Institution in Fort Alexander: a larger range for our kitchen, and an oven for our bakery.

RANGE---They bought the actual range 22 years when the School was opened with 45 children. Now it is superannuated, broken, and far too small for one hundred persons that are living in the house.

Our desires would be to have a large institution range, having two fires burning wood, one shelf, a canopy, and a good ventilation in the chimney to draw the smell of the kitchen.

BAKE OVEN---The actual oven is not quite so old as the kitchen range, but it is too small for our needs, and it is not giving satisfaction.
taking too long for cooking. It takes the whole day to cook one bag of flour, and the last loaves are always sour. Some weeks we are obliged to bake five times at one bag at the time... So we need a larger and better bake oven for the School.

In the southern part of Manitoba, at Aubigny, there is an oven for sale. It is a second hand one indeed, but in very good shape and doing good work. It's one of those metallic ovens called "Economic", made by Mr. Jean Daoust from Saint Boniface.

That bake oven complete, with 30 dripping pans made especially for it, is for offer for $300.00 cash. The freight with the installation will cost about $50.00 more.

The same bake ovens new (8 ft. long, -5 ft. high, -3 ft. deep.) cost $450.00 F.O.B.

That second hand oven I speak about has been in use only two or three months. The owner is not using it any more because he had a bad accident in one of his arms.

Hoping you will give a favorable answer to my requests, I remain, dear Sir,

Yours very respectfully,

[Signature]

REGINA, SASK., August 10, 1925

Dear Mr. Graham:

According to your instructions, I beg to say that I left Regina on the night of July 15th, for the purpose of attending to several matters in Manitoba and visiting different points. While I was there I visited the Fort Alexander School and Reserve. The school is situated on the Winnipeg River, about three miles up from the mouth where the river empties into Lake Winnipeg. It is a very difficult place to get at, owing to the fact that it takes a long time to get word to the school to meet the train at Victoria Beach, and there is no boat at Travers Bay now, from where it is the most direct way to get to the school. It is, therefore, necessary to get a boat at Victoria Beach, and as the boat-house is on the West side of the point it takes sixteen miles of travelling to get around to the East side, and then about 14 miles from there across the lake to the school.

The Fort Alexander Reserve lies on both sides of the Winnipeg River for a distance of about nine miles from the mouth, and the settlement is all on the banks of the river. In most places

the banks are fairly high, with a narrow strip of prairie running back from the river to the bush. Some of the Indians have fairly good houses, built of logs a story and a half high with shingled roofs. A few of them have frame houses, and then, of course, we have the old-time shacks as well. At the time of my visit most of the Indians were away picking berries. The ones who were at home I saw at the school. The only way of getting around the reserve was on foot or by boat up the river, as there are no roads to travel on. I understand that it is a difficult proposition to get hay here on account of the country being mostly all wooded, and the Indians cut a lot of their hay with scythes, in small sloughs back in the bush, as there is very little hay on the open land along the river. Very few of the Indians raise any garden truck, although the soil along the river is excellent for gardening, as I was up to a settlement which adjoins the reserve which was settled up by Eastern Frenchmen some forty years ago, where they raise excellent grains and garden stuff and have been very successful in mixed farming. Ever since the settlement started, and until the road was put through to Lac du Bonnet, these people had to market their stuff in Selkirk, so that if the Indians had been properly encouraged I think they could have done a lot more than they are doing at the present time. They are simply existing on the reserve. They make their living by hunting and fishing and picking berries in the summertime, and the Indians whom I saw complained that at certain times of the year they were very hard up, as the game and fish here were getting very scarce.
CATTLE

There is supposed to be about 500 head of cattle on this reserve. I, however, doubt very much if there are that many, as I do not believe they have ever been counted by the Agent, and I am quite sure if they were tallied there would be a big shortage. The only count that ever has been taken has been by getting the number that each one owns from the Indians themselves. I saw quite a number, possibly most of the cattle, along the river in small bunches here and there, and I must say that the stock is of a very poor quality, which can be accounted for by the fact that the Indians allow the bull calves to run without paying any attention to them and each cattle owner is practically raising his own bulls, with the result that the stock has become inbred.

PORT ALEXANDER INDIAN BOARDING SCHOOL

The main building of this school was erected in 1904. An addition was built to it in 1914 and a second addition in 1923. The size of the present building is 42x140 - three-storey. The building site is right on the banks of the river, and is beautifully situated. The Catholic Mission house and church are also situated here and only a few yards from the school. The number of pupils resident at the school is 85. Of course during my visit they were all away on their holidays. With the staff this makes about 100 people in the school. The school is lighted by electricity and there is running water in the building. The power house is situated right on the bank of the river, and about 300 feet from the school. The water is pumped with an engine from the river, and forced up to tanks
in the attic of the building, and from there, of course, by gravity through the school. The electric light is supplied by the same engine, dynamo and batteries, but as this engine was only a 9 h.p. it was deemed too small to run the plant satisfactorily and a 16 h.p. "Y" type engine from the Fairbanks-Morse Company was supplied to this school last winter. Brother Gauthier was installing this engine while I was there, and they were putting up a new building to house the power plant. The laundry of the school is done by using three or four hand power washing machines. They have a steam boiler in the laundry for supplying hot water. The school is well kept and the grounds around the school have been well looked after; the space between the river and the school being fixed up with nice flower beds and a lawn. They also farm about 100 acres of land and the crop consists of garden truck, several acres of peas, 14 acres of potatoes, oats, barley, wheat and hay. The garden has been well looked after, and the crop in general looked splendid. The school building is in a very good state of repair, having been painted outside only two or three years ago when the new addition was put on. The interior of the building is also in fair shape, having been well looked after by the Sisters. The new addition, of course, is in first class shape and needs no attention. The other part of the school is not as good as the new part, still it was in fair shape, with the exception of a few places where the plaster was loose and would have to be re-plastered. The halls had been painted a dark green some years ago, which makes them very dark, and
this was some of the work that Father Bousquet wanted to have done and on your instructions I had $900.00 to spend on the painting. I must say that I was very sorry Father Bousquet was absent from the school at the time of my visit, being away to the opening of the Duck Lake School, which I did not know until I arrived at the school. I, however, went over the work with the Sister Superior and the Father who is assistant principal. I had a painter with me from Winnipeg who went with me for the purpose of figuring on the work and giving me a quotation. The price he gave me as he returned back with me to Winnipeg amounted to about $1750.00, and after checking it over with him thoroughly, I considered that his price was much too high, as it amounted to approximately 30¢ a yard, and as about half of it was one-coat work I thought this was out of reason altogether, but he explained to me that it was a hard place to get at and would necessitate considerable scaffolding and ladder work, as some of the rooms had 16' ceilings, and besides it would cost about $70.00 for plaster work. The next day after arriving in Winnipeg I went down to Selkirk with a view of trying to get hold of a painter, and while there I got in touch with a Mr. Esfeld and a Mr. Mabee. The former agreed to do the work at 18¢ for two-coat work and 10¢ for single coat work, and we were to pay for his transportation, and the school to board him and his men while on the job. The quotation of the latter man was 25¢ per yard for two-coat work and 15¢ for single coat work. I made arrangements with the lowest tenderer, Mr. Esfeld, to go up the following Monday and I wired from Winnipeg to the boat owner
at Victoria Beach to get word to the school, if possible, to meet the painter the following Monday; if not, he was to take him to the school. At Mr. Sefeld's price we were going to be able to do practically all the work that was required this year, and keep within the allowance of $900.00. However, before I left Winnipeg I arranged with Mr. Bunn that should anything happen that Mr. Sefeld should not go on with the work after seeing it, that he was to accept Mr. Mabee's tender of 15 and 25¢, as Mr. Mabee advised me that he would go out any time that he was wanted. You will, therefore, see that I took all precautions possible to make sure that this work would be done, at the same time endeavoring to have it performed for a reasonable price. The very thing that I was afraid of happened; after seeing the work, Sefeld backed down on the job and the work was given to Mr. Mabee. This, of course, caused a few days delay, which was unavoidable. As there is about 4500 yards of inside painting to do, at this price there will only be money available to do about two-thirds of the work.

The following requirements were brought to my attention while going over the school:

1. The batteries in the lighting plant are worn out, and Brother Gauthier, who was installing the new engine there, advised me that they were absolutely useless. They were furnished some four or five years ago. There are 56 cells and the present battery is a Globelite.

2. As I mentioned before, there are three tanks in the attic of the school, into which the water is pumped from the river. These are very unsanitary as there is nothing over them but a few loose boards. They are also practically worn out; one being out of commission.
new and the other two I was informed are continually springing a leak and spoiling the plaster on the ceiling. In putting up the new power house to house the plant, a cement basement was put under the building where pressure tanks can be stored, and the request of the school is that they be furnished with two pressure tanks this fall if possible, and if not this fall, then without fail next spring.

3. The Sister Superior also brought to my attention the fact that she had repeatedly asked for a power washing machine and extractor, pointing out that as there are approximately 100 people in the school to wash for, it was a very difficult matter to get this done by hand machines. Their idea is now to take the 9 h.p. engine that has been taken out of the power plant and place it in the laundry and in the event of a washer and extractor being supplied, this engine will furnish the power. I have no doubt but what this is required, and if it cannot be supplied out of this year's appropriation I am quite sure the Sister Superior would be satisfied if she were told that it would be supplied next spring.

4. In another year the shingles on the roof of the school should have another coat of stain, and this expenditure should be provided for in the Estimates this year; also whatever painting is not completed this year in the interior of the building, as the amount I have mentioned requires painting.

5. I also wish to bring to your attention that at the time the first school was built the laundry was separate from the main building and connected by a passage. When the new addition was put on three years ago the old laundry was abandoned and a laundry room was provided in the new addition. The old laundry building is a frame structure.
a storey and a half, 22 x 34 with a basement. The foundation has heaved and is crumbling up, and if there is nothing done the building will all go to wreck in a short time. No doubt the school will soon be asking for additional room and it seems a pity to see this building going to wreck. It would, of course, cost considerable to repair it, but it would certainly pay to do so. It would have to be placed on a new foundation and all the basement walls and floor would have to be renewed, and there would be considerable plaster to fix up etc.

I might also mention that the Department supplied this school with a new barn about three years ago, at a cost of twelve or fourteen thousand dollars.

From the foregoing you will see that considerable money has been spent here on the education of Indians, and I must say that I fail to see where they have bettered their conditions in any way. I, of course, am not familiar with what conditions were on this reserve years ago, but I could not see where any recent improvements had been made. The Sisters in the school, I am quite sure, do good work among the Indian women, as they spend a lot of their time among them, teaching them how to cook, sew and look after their children properly etc., but the men have certainly not taken any advantage of the education they received in the school. I must say that I was sorry Mr. Latulippe, the Agent, was away, as I would have had him with me on this trip. As an Agent he is accomplishing nothing. I am willing to admit that the fact of him living in Selkirk makes it difficult to do much with Indians at Fort Alexander. He certainly cannot do much by making a trip to Fort Alexander, staying overnight and going back the next day. There is no reason at all why he could not
spend a week now and again on this reserve. People living on the edge of the reserve are making a good living by mixed farming, and these Indians are not the long-haired type that we have on many of the reserves in Saskatchewan, but are mostly half-breeds; in fact a number of them look as though they have very little Indian blood in them, and with proper supervision by an Agent who had some ability, something could be accomplished on the reserve in the way of advancement. At the present time it is dormant; in fact you will realize it would be going back, as the Indians were much better off a few years ago when fur was plentiful.

Sir:

I am enclosing herewith a report of a trip made to the Fort Alexander School and Reserve by Inspector Christianson on July 15th. The report is most interesting, but shows that the Principal, Father Bousquet, is apparently not co-operating with the Department and I am not at all surprised at this, as I know that the Church's representative is doing all he can to place our officers in a distinctly bad light before the Department, and, I am sorry to say, with some results. It was at this school where the Principal made most serious charges against this Inspector when he last visited the institution, which have turned out to be not only untrue but malicious, and this sort of thing is bound to go on unless the Department take a decided stand.

I must say that the impression I have is that the officers of the Department are very often placed in most awkward positions through the Department not upholding them when they are in the right. The Department too often rely entirely on the information they get from one side, even going so far as to instruct the carrying out of repairs and alterations that are unnecessary, and when your officers in the field point this out they are brought into conflict with the church authorities, which is not at all satisfactory.

According to the Inspector he is of the opinion that a lot of this work that we are called upon to do, if not all of it, could be done by the school authorities. Instead of that, it would seem that they will not move a foot in this direction, but call upon the Department for everything. This is such a contrast to Portage la Prairie, where they appreciate any little assistance that the Government give them, and where it is possible for them to get the work done themselves they do so. This unsatisfactory situation has sprung up within the last three years, and while my understanding is that the schools are to do as much as they can to keep their buildings in repair, the authorities at this particular school are certainly not under that impression.

It is unpleasant for me to write a letter of this kind, but I see matters getting worse all the time and our Inspectors being placed in a position which they should not be placed in. I am prepared at any time to show the Department where its weaknesses are in the management of Indian schools.

The Inspector has made certain recommendations regarding requirements at this school. I think these recommendations should be acted upon.

In connection with the painting which is now under way. I got a long distance call from the Principal, Father Bousquet, who was absent at the time of the Inspector's visit. (He should not have been absent without advising this office), in which he informed me that seven or eight trips had to be made back and forth. The Inspector tells me that he cannot understand why there should have been more than two trips. It would appear that there has been no effort on the part of the Principal to get this work done, but that he was more anxious to place obstacles in the way. I understand from the Inspector that the Department supplied this institution with a gasoline boat; if so, why are we charged with seven or eight trips even if it were necessary to make them, which it was not.

The whole
The whole situation, as I have said before, is getting worse, and the Department are not doing much to make matters better. Sooner or later the whole thing will have to be changed. You have got in Mr. Latulippe an Agent who, in my opinion, is almost worthless. The Inspector in Manitoba is an old man, not practical and very extravagant, and is easily influenced by others in the matter of expenditure, which was plainly demonstrated in the mix-up which we got into at Elkhorn. Unless the Indian Agent at this point is changed we are not going to accomplish much on the reserves. It is true we will have an additional Inspector in connection with this office, who will be promoted from one of our qualified Agents, but it is not inspections that are lacking here, it is a qualified Agent.

I have understood that the great repairs made in the Indian Schools are at the charges of the Indian Department, and have not to be paid by the principals with the money of the children's grant. Sir:

I am herewith attaching a letter just received from Father Bousquet, Principal of Fort Alexander School.

I wish to inform you that I sent Inspector Christianson up to the School on the 20th ultimo, for the purpose of arranging for the painting. I had previously written to Father Bousquet, stating that an Inspector would leave here about the 15th July, and further asking him if there was anyone in that neighborhood he could get to do this work. He informed me that there were no men up there capable of doing the work. It would therefore be necessary to bring a man in from Winnipeg. Mr. Christianson brought a painter from Winnipeg to the school for the purpose of figuring on the work. When they arrived there the Inspector found that Father Bousquet was at Duck Lake, but was expected back the following day. The Inspector, along with the painter, the Sister Superior and the Vice-Principal, went over the school and found that there would be about 4500 yards of inside painting to do. The price given by Mr. Coats, the painter, on this work, amounted to approximately $1800.00—that is for material and work. As we had purchased the material at approximately $400.00, the work would amount to about $1400.00, and there being only $900 to purchase the material and to do the work, this man's figure could not be accepted. Mr. Christianson then went to Selkirk to see if he could not get someone there to undertake the work at a lower price. He got prices there from two different painters who did most of the work in that town—a Mr. Isfeld and a Mr. Mabee. The former's price was .10 for a one-coat job and .15 for a two-coat one; and the latter man's price was .25 for two coats and .15 for one coat. The Inspector made arrangements with Mr. Isfeld, who quoted the lower figure, and he was to go up there the following Monday, which he did, along with two men. Whatever

Happened after he arrived at the school, he would not go on with the work, and came to Winnipeg to get a plasterer. The following day Mr. Bunn notified me that Mr. Isfeld had decided not to go back to the school, although he had left his two men there. I then instructed him to get Mr. Mabee to do the work.

At the price quoted by Isfeld on the work, we would have been able to do most of the work required this year, but as Mr. Mabee's figures are much higher, only about two-thirds of the work can be done this year. I notified Father Bousquet that he could spend $500 on the actual work of painting. There is sufficient material bought to do all the work required.

You will note from the Reverend gentleman's letter that he is again very peev'd. You will remember he wrote a very sarcastic letter last summer. Evidently Father Bousquet wants to have the whole say in the management of the school and the expending of money in connection with the Institution, as any interference from this office does not meet with his approval. I think it is about high time the Department advised him that they had something to say in regard to expenditures and the management of the Institution. I also think it is an imposition for Boarding Schools to call on the Department to bring in men from outside to do painting or ordinary repairing around the buildings. The older boys might just as well be doing this work, as learning to work is part of their education. Other Institutions are willing at all times to do this work, if we furnish the material. I might just mention one instance—Mr. Henry at the Boarding School in Portage la Prairie had his boys paint the building, and he has made the statement several times that they could do it just as well as any of the painters he could hire and that he would certainly never ask the Department to furnish him with labor to do the work as long as they supplied him with material. If this work can be done successfully in this way at one place, it can be done at another.

Father Bousquet is not trying to co-operate with this office at all, and I think the Department should make it plain to him that he will be expected to carry out instructions that are issued from this office.

Dear Father Bousquet:

Correspondence which you have had with Mr. Commissioner Graham, of Regina, has been brought to my attention, and I am writing to ask you to cooperate fully with our Regina office in connection with painting the school and any other repairs or replacements which the Department places in the hands of Mr. Commissioner Graham or any other of our officers. At Indian residential schools, it is the practice to ask the management to make all small repairs necessary to keep the buildings and equipment in good condition, and to cooperate with the Department and its officials in any replacements or major building activities for which Parliament has voted money. The school staff and older boys should give their labour without compensation. Vocational training will thus be received. Further, the Department expects you to assist with your motor boat in the transportation of workers and in the freighting of materials.

I regret that it is necessary to direct this letter to you, but Mr. Commissioner Graham, who has the painting in hand and whose instructions you should follow, is not convinced that you are cooperating as well as is expected.

Dear Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th ultimo #125-1-5, asking me wherein the Inspector's report shows that the Reverend Principal of the Fort Alexander School is not cooperating with the Department.

I may say that when my covering letter was written I was under the impression that the Rev. Principal's letter of the 8th of August had not been forwarded to you, and it was my intention to attach this letter to the report, as I had had a long talk with the Inspector on the Fort Alexander situation and he was, and is still of the opinion that cooperation with the Department in getting work done at this institution is lacking. The Principal's letter, I think, would bear out the Inspector's contention. You are now being called upon to pay for seven or eight trips in bringing out material or men in connection with the painting of the school, which I think could have been cut down considerably had business methods been applied.

I may say that since writing to you on the 17th ultimo I have seen Father Bousquet and he informs me that it was necessary for him to hire a boat to make some of these trips. All I can say is that the Inspector went down there and thought everything was settled and it is rather a surprise to be asked to pay for all these additional trips.

Sir,

I beg to forward copy of a letter from Revd. Father Bousquet relating to the painting just completed at the Fort Alexander School. After stating that he is quite satisfied with the work he goes on to say that he did not choose the colors and that the cream colored paint sent was too yellow. As a matter of fact the colors were chosen by the Revd. Father from a color list sent to him and the paint was purchased from the lowest tenderer after securing competitive prices. It is just possible that the tint of the successful tenderer was a little deeper than that of the manufacturer whose list the color was chosen from, but it is a very simple matter for a painter to make the paint a shade lighter or deeper as may be required and this would have been done by anyone overseeing the work if sufficiently interested.

The account he sends in amounts to $222.70 and comprises $39.00 for freight, $13.50 wages of a plasterer's helper and $170.20 for board at 50¢ per meal.

It is evident that the amount allowed for this work has been exceeded, but I am not yet in a position to say by exactly how much.

Cher monsieur,

J'ai reçu votre lettre du 29 dernier, me disant que le Commissaire de Régina, monsieur Graham se plaignait de ce je ne l'aidais pas dans les travaux que le Gouvernement faisait exécuter dans notre école, surtout dans le travail de peinture qui vient de se terminer.

Permettez-moi, cher monsieur, de vous dire que je ne vois pas en quoi je suis coupable. Voilà 23 ans que je suis en charge d'écoles indiennes; j'ai toujours mis en pratique ce que vous avez eu la bonté de me rappeler dans votre lettre du 29. J'ai toujours aidé le Gouvernement à faire le moins de dépenses dans les écoles soit en faisant les travaux nous-mêmes quand cela était possible, soit en dépensant le moins possible quand on me chargeait de les faire exécuter. Jusqu'à ce jour les agents et les inspecteurs n'ont eu que des éloges pour mon travail et ma manière de faire... Je crois que monsi-
Graham parlerait à leur mission s'il n'était pas dans l'erreur, ou guidé par un autre désir que celui de faire connaître la vérité au Gouvernement d'Ottawa.

Monsieur Graham m'accuse de n'avoir pas employé à la peinture le personnel et les garçons d'école, et de n'avoir pas transporté les peintres et les matériaux avec notre bateau à gazoline.

Ayez la bonté de lire la réponse à toutes ces accusations.

10...LES ENFANTS D'ECOLE, au mois d'août et commencement de septembre, étaient en vacances. Comment pouvais-je retenir les faire travailler à la peinture de l'école? Quand monsieur Graham écrivait cette accusation, il savait parfaitement par ma correspondance que les enfants étaient en vacances. Et alors?

20...LE PERSONNEL... Je ne parlerai pas des religieuses, car je suppose que monsieur Graham n'a pas la prétention de les voir grimper sur les tréteaux et les voir faire de la peinture. Aussi je passe au reste du personnel qui me reste, consistant en mon assistant qui est prêtre et malade, mon fermier et un Frère Oblat.

Le fermier, au mois d'août et de septembre n'a guère le temps de faire de la peinture; c'est le moment des moissons ou des foins. Il a même plus de tra-
vail qu'il ne peut en faire. Je suis même obligé de lui fournir d'autres hommes pour l'aider.

Le Frère Oplat... a fait tous les réparages en bois en avant des peintres, soit aux armoires, soit aux portes et aux fenêtres. Avec le reste du personnel, il a huilé 6 grands planchers, peint et émaillé 35 lits, réparé et verni tous les bureaux de classe. Tout ce travail que je viens d'énumérer est énorme, et avait besoin d'être fait pendant les vacances. Si vous regardez l'état de comptes envoyé avant de recevoir votre lettre, vous ne trouverez pas que je demande une indemnité au Gouvernement pour tout ce travail. Il a été fait gratis.

Le BATEAU A GASOLINE... C'est vrai, je n'ai pas employé au début notre bateau pour transporter les matériaux et les peintres, et cela pour la bonne raison qu'en ce moment il était au réparateur. J'ai dû attendre 15 jours pour avoir les pièces de rechange; et le tout, avec le travail, m'a coûté environ $ 35.00.

Quand monsieur Graham écrivait que je n'employais pas notre bateau pour les transports, il ne savait pas dans quelles difficultés je me trouvais en ce moment là. Depuis lors il les a connus; mais je doute fort qu'il vous écrive pour faire amende honorable.

Sur l'état de comptes, vous pourrez constater que rien n'a été de-
mandé pour renvoyer les peintres au chemin de fer,
car c'est notre bateau qui les y a ramenés.

Une discussion au sujet de la pension
des peintres. Monsieur Graham désirait que l'école donne
la pension gratis. Je lui ai répondu simplement que je
ne croyais pas être obligé à la donner gratuitement en
ce cas, vu que le montant de cette pension serait trop
élevé pour les moyens de notre école. En effet il s'agit
d'une somme de $150.00. Jusqu'ici le Département a
compris que des pareils montants ne devaient pas être
à la charge des écoles, les écoles pensionnaires où le
grant est loin d'égaliser les écoles industrielles ou au-
tres. Aussi j'espère être remboursé sans difficulté
de la part du Gouvernement.

Excusez, cher monsieur, la longueur de cette
lettre. Mais j'ai cru que les accusations de monsieur
Graham méritaient d'être mises dans le véritable jour.

Je me souscris, cher monsieur,

Votre tout respectueux.

Sir:

I have received your letter of the 29th ultimo, advising me that the Commissioner of Regina, Mr. Graham, was complaining that I was not helping him in the work the Government was having done at our school, especially in the painting which has just been done.

Permit me, Dear Sir, to tell you that I can not see where I am guilty. I have been in charge of the Indian schools for twenty-three years; I have always practiced what you were kind enough to remind me of in your letter of the 29th. I have always helped the Government to do with the least expenditure in our schools whether by doing the work ourselves when it was possible, or by spending as little as possible when I had to have the work done otherwise. So far the Agents and Inspectors had only praise for my work and the way I handled it. I believe that Mr. Graham would speak the same way if he was not mistaken, or guided by another desire than that of communicating the truth to the Government at Ottawa.

Mr. Graham accuses me of having not employed for the painting the staff of the school made up of school boys, and of not having transported the painters and the material with our gasoline boat.

Kindly read my answer to these accusations.

1st: The school children, during the months of August and the beginning of September were on their holidays. How could I retain them and have them do the painting of the school? When Mr. Graham was writing this accusation, he knew perfectly well by my correspondence that the children were on their holidays, and what of it?

2nd: The staff,...I will not speak of the Reverend Sisters, as I suppose that Mr. Graham does not expect to see them climb up scaffolds to do any painting. I, therefore, pass to the remainder of the staff under my direction, consisting of my assistant who is a Priest and who is ill, my farmer and an Oblate Brother.
The Farmer, in the month of August and September has hardly any time to do painting; it is the time of harvest and hay making. He has even more work than he can do. I have often to get him help.

The Oblate Brother... has done all the repairs to the woodwork ahead of the painters, to the cupboards as well as the doors and windows. With the remainder of the staff he oiled six (6) large floors, painted and enamelled eighty-five (85) beds, repaired and varnished all the class room doors. All this work which I have enumerated is enormous and needed to be done during the holidays. If you look at the accounts sent before receiving your letter, you will not find that I am asking an indemnity of the Government for all this work. It was all done for nothing.

Concerning the gasoline launch... It is quite true that I did not use at the beginning, our launch to convey the material and the painters and this for the good reason that it was being repaired. I had to wait fifteen (15) days to get parts to replace the broken ones and all this with the labour has cost me about $35.00. When Mr. Graham was writing that I was not using our launch for the transportation, he did not know the difficulty I was meeting at that time. He has learned of them since, but I doubt that he will write to make any apology.

On the statement of the account you will find that nothing was charged for sending the painters to the railroad as it was our launch which carried them over.

There is a discussion concerning the painters board. Mr. Graham wanted the school to give them their board gratuitously. I simply replied that I did not believe that I was obliged to give them their board free in this case, as the amount of the board would be too high for the means of our school. It amounts really to $150.00 so far the Department has understood that such amounts could not be charged to the school, especially to the boarding schools where the grant is far from being equal to that of the industrial and other schools. I, therefore, hope to be reimbursed without any difficulty by the Department.

Kind excuse the length of this letter, but I thought that it was necessary to put the accusations brought against me by Mr. Graham in the proper light.

Yours, etc.,

P. Bourgret.
O. M. I.

Sir:

I am forwarding herewith a voucher submitted by the Rev. Principal of the Fort Alexander School for $232.70 in connection with the painting at that institution. You will note that this voucher includes motor trips from Traverse Bay to the School, and the board of men performing the work there. The receipts in payment of the boat hire are also attached.

In a previous letter to the Department dated the 13th of August I furnished full particulars in regard to the arrangements made for the painting at this school.

In regard to the boat transportation I was under the impression, of course, that the conveyance of the material and the painters would be undertaken by the School Launch, but the Principal has informed me that his boat was not repaired at the time.

I suggested to the Principal that as only $900.00 had been allotted for the work to be done he should undertake to board the painters free of charge, but this he declined to do, and submits an account for board for 100 days at $1.50 per day or at the rate of fifty-cents per meal. I consider this charge excessive and out of reason. If the Principal had been desirous of collaborating with the Department he might well have provided meals for the painters without payment, but if he considered this a strain on his resources he should at least not have charged more than what would have covered the bare cost. I cannot recommend payment of this last item of which indeed he gives no details, and this of course he ought to be called upon to submit in any event.

While $900.00 only was allowed, as was explained to the Principal, the total cost as recorded here is over $1500.00.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

The new engine, type Diesel, and the new set of batteries that you had the kindness to obtain for us are installed and give perfect satisfaction. That installation could have been finished long time ago if Brother Bug. Gauthier had not been called elsewhere for urgent matters, and distracted from his work during nearly two months.

Quite heavy expenses were caused by the installation of this new set of machines; and I take the liberty to lay before you the different vouchers with the desire to be reimbursed by the Indian Department. Ourselves we have made most of the carpentry work, all the cartage of material, the setting of machines, etc...

So I expect to not have any trouble to get back the cash money we have spent.
I am to give you in few words, dear Sir, the reasons and causes of those different expenses.

BUILDING.

We had to build a place where to put the new machines, for the old ones, far smaller than these, were in the carpentry shop, exposed to the dust and the hands of everybody. The building we have made has a concrete basement, and a ground floor only.

The basement, at present, is used as root cellar; but in the near future, it will become the room of a compressed water tank, for our actual tanks, located in the attic of the School building, and 22 years old, are rotten and insalubrious.

The ground floor of our new building is divided in three rooms of different sizes.

One of them, the largest, (14 ft. x 20 ft.) is specially devoted to our electric plant, which consists in 56 cells, one switch board, a generator of 7 kilowatts, and a 15 H.P. Diesel engine cooled by a water tank of 5 ft. diameter, and 7 ft. high.

The other two rooms are used to store some of our supplies, and are to take the place of two old logs buildings that are a disgrace in the neighborhood.
of the School.

I can say again what I have said to you in a letter of the 22 of June: "Everything has been built warm indeed, but in the most cheapest way." And Mr. Christianson known that I say the truth, for he has seen everything in his last trip to Fort Alexander.

FITTINGS & FIXTURES.

Having to put up machines entirely different of the old ones in speed and in sizes, we had to get new pulleys, new shafts, new straps, etc... to make everything work together. Most of these material was bought from Canadian Fairbanks-Morse Co.; and the rest from Ashdown or Marshall/Wells Co., that is to say from firms selling at the wholesale.

I hope these explanations will be sufficient to prove you that we have not wasted money, but we have spent the strict necessary only. We had to install machines and make them work; so it has been necessary to build a place, and buy the necessary fixtures, to obtain a good result.

Please, Sir, accept my best thanks for the help you gave us to get a new engine and new set of batteries; but I ask you to continue your kindness toward s
us in sending my vouchers and having them paid in Ottawa the soonest possible.

I remain, Sir,

Yours respectfully,

Sir:

Last fall I received authority to put the Electric Lighting Plant at the Fort Alexander Boarding School in proper working condition, and on the 2nd of March I forwarded a voucher covering payment of a new 15 H.P. Fairbanks-Morse engine. In February I received a letter from Mr. J.R. Bunn reporting that the engine had not been installed owing to difficulty of placing the new engine on the old foundation, and advising me that Brother Eugene Gentier who was to make the installation had advised the school authorities to build an addition to the machine shop and place the new engine therein. Mr. Bunn further advised me that the Principal intended to act upon this suggestion and expected to erect this addition at his own expense.

Since then I have had no correspondence with the Principal of the School on the subject, but a day or two ago received a letter dated the 7th of November enclosing accounts to the amount of $1338.66 representing items of expenditure in connection with the installation which he asks the Department to pay. It will be noted that this expenditure extends over a period of more than five months, and if the Principal wished and expected to be reimbursed by the Department, the expenditure he undertook he should certainly have brought the matter to the attention of the Department before, and given an estimate of the probable cost.

The Principal of this school seldom offers co-operation in undertakings designed for the benefit of his school, and his attitude in regard to the painting which was done this summer is another illustration of this characteristic. I cannot recommend payment of these accounts, and forward them to the Department to take what action it desires. The enclosures comprise copy of the Principal's letter of the 7th November, together with a statement of the accounts enclosed, a number of which are merely copies and not originals. I have duplicates of the statement and accounts which I am retaining here pending the Department's instructions.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham

November 7 1926

Mr. W.M. Graham, Indian Commissioner,
Regina.

Sir,

The new engine, type Deisel, and the new set of batteries that you had the kindness to obtain for us, are installed and give perfect satisfaction. That installation could have been finished long time ago if Revd. Brother Gauthier had not been called elsewhere for urgent matters, and distracted from his work during two months.

Quite heavy expenses were caused by the installation of this new set of machines; and I take the liberty to lay before you the different vouchers, with the desire to be reimbursed by the Indian Department. Ourselves we have made most of the carpentry work, all the cartage of material, the setting of machines, etc.,... So I expect to not have any trouble to get back the cash money we have spent.

I am to give in few words, dear Sir, the reasons and causes of those different expenses.

BUILDING---

We had to build a place to put the new machines, for the old one, far smaller than these, were in the carpentry shop, exposed to the dust and to the hand of everybody. Anyway there was no room enough for them.

The building we have made has a con-
crete floor basement, and a ground floor only.

The basement, at present, is used as root cellar; but in the near future, it will become the room for air compressed water tanks, for our actual tanks, located in the attic of the School, and 23 years old, are rotten and insalubrious.

The ground floor of the new building is divided in three rooms of different sizes.

One of them, the largest, (14 ft. x 20 ft.) is specially devoted to our electric plant, which consists in 56 cells, one switch board, a generator of 7 kilowatts, and a 15 H.P. Diesel engine cooled by water coming from a tank of 5 ft. diameter, and 7 ft. high.

The other rooms are used to store some of our supplies, and are to take the place of 2 old buildings that are a disgrace in the neighborhood of the School.

I can say again what I have said to you in my letter of the 22d. of June: "Everything has been built warm indeed, but in the cheapest way! Mr. Christensen knows what I say is very true, for he everything in his last trip to Fort Alexander."

---- FITTINGS & FIXTURES. ----

Having to put up machines entirely different from the old ones in speed and in sizes, we had to get new pulleys, new shafts, new straps, etc... to make everything work right together. Most of these materials were bought from Fairbanks Morse Co., and the rest from Ashdown or Marshall-Wells Co., that is from firms selling at the wholesale.

I hope those explanations will be sufficient to prove you that we have not wasted money, but we have spent the strict necessary only. We
had to install machines and make them work; so it was necessary to build a place where to put them, and buy the necessary fixtures to have a good result.

Please, Sir, accept my best thanks for the help you gave us to get the new engine and the new set of batteries; but I ask you to continue your kindness towards us in secending my vouchers and having them paid in Ottawa the soonest possible.

I remain, sir,

Yours respectfully,

P. BOUSQUET/OMI.
École Indienne

Fort Alexandre, Man.

16 janvier 1926.

Monsieur Duncan C. Scott,
Superintendant Général des Aff. Indiennes.

Ottawa.

Cher Monsieur,

Je prends la liberté de vous écrire pour certaines sommes d'argent qui furent dépensées, l'été dernier, à l'école du Fort Alexandre, et que le Secrétaire du Bureau des Indiens refuse de rembourser sous prétexte qu'elles ne furent jamais autorisées. Je suis certain, cher Monsieur, qu'après avoir pris connaissance de la présente lettre, vous admettrez la légitimité de mes réclamations à ce sujet.

Au mois de novembre 1924, le Bureau des Affaires Indiennes accorda à notre école une machine Deisel, actionnée au pétrole brut, pour faire l'électricité de notre éclairage. Cette machine n'arriva au Fort Alexandre que dans le mois de janvier, et fut installée, dans le courant de l'été dernier par le frère Eug. Cauchier.

Comme il avait été convenu avec monsieur Graham, l'école n'a pas exigé de paiement de la part du Gouvernement pour l'ouvrage de ce bon Frère; mais elle a été obligée cependant de lui payer la somme de $150,00 pour ses gages.

Maintenant ici vient le point en litige... Qui doit payer le matériel et le travail
pour cette installation ?...Cette nouvelle machi-
ne étant d'une grosseur et d'une vitesse différen-
te de l'ancienne, il a fallu acheter de nouvelles
courrois et des poulies; qui doit payer tout cela?
Le secrétaire du Bureau des Affaires Indiennes pré-
tend que ces dépenses n'ont pas été autorisées. Quan
à moi, je suis d'opinion contraire, car elles ont été
autorisées par monsieur Graham directement ou indi-
rectement. Peut-être ce monsieur l'a nier auprès d
du Gouvernement; mais en quelques mots je vais essa-
yer de démontrer qu'il l'a fait.

Voici un extrait d'une lettre venant
de monsieur Bunn de Winnipeg, datée du 26 novembre
1924.

Dear Sir,

Commissioner Graham of Regina was in
my office a.m. to meet Revd. Brother Bag. Gauthier
with reference to a new gasoline engine for your
School lighting plant...I am enclosing herewith
the blue print plans for the new foundation that will
be required...You should provide ample quantities
of sand, gravel and cement required for this, without
any delay..."

Cette lettre me donne des ordres de l
la part de monsieur Graham par l'intermédiaire de
monsieur Bunn de Winnipeg; et ils sont bien clairs.

Maintenant prenons dans la corres
-dance de monsieur le Commissaire lui-même.
Regina. February 5 1925.

Dear Sir,...I arranged with the Company to
send a man down to see that the engine was proper-
ly installed,and I shall be glad if you will advise
me if this was done....

Extrait d'une autre lettre, datée
du 14 février.

Dear Sir,...I gave instructions to
have this engine installed when the purchase was
made,and you not yet informed me whether the instal-
lation has been made or not....
En écrivant ces différentes lettres, et d'autres, hélas! que je n'ai pas conservées pensant qu'elles ne me seraient jamais utiles..., votre représentant de Régina avait bien l'intention de donner des ordres, et les donnait en effet; et, moi, je n'avais qu'à obéir sans réclamer. Où prenait-il ses droits de commandant? J'ai toujours supposé qu'il les tenait d'Ottawa. Et, au mois de juin, sans arrière-pensée, j'ai commencé les constructions, car au mois de février je lui avais donné les raisons qui me faisaient renvoyer le travail à plus tard. Voici les explications que je lui donnais:

sur mon... We have received the engine, but we don't work to put it in place. We are waiting for the nice season. There is a lot of cement work to be done, and buildings will have to be opened. It will not be wise to expose everything to freeze. Anyway we cannot get sand and stones in winter for foundations."

Comme je l'ai dit à monsieur Graham dans une lettre accompagnant le compte des dépenses que je lui ai présenté au mois de novembre dernier, et dont je vous envoie copie, l'installation de ces machines est exigé une maison spéciale, car il était impossible de les placer là où se trouvait l'ancienne. (Monsieur Bunn, ainsi que monsieur Christianson peuvent corroborer ça que j'avance, parce qu'ils ont vu l'endroit où se trouvait l'ancienne machine.)

J'avoue que la maison que nous avons faite est plus grande que... n'exige les machines électriques; mais elle a été faite en prévision de l'avenir. Et si, monsieur Scott, croit ne pas pouvoir accorder le montant complet demandé, je le prie de vouloir bien nous accorder la moitié de cette somme. Et plus tard quand on voudra employer le reste de la bâtisse pour y placer des réservoirs à pression, le Gouvernement nous accordera le reste, car tout l'argent engagé là-dedans appartient à la Congrégation des Oblats, y
ayant placé avec permission mon salaire et une partie de celui de mon assistant.

Je vous ai écrit en toute confiance, cher Monsieur; vous exposant les faits tels qu'ils sont.

Je regrette de vous retenir si longtemps sur cette question d'argent; mais pour nous cette somme est trop importante pour que je doive pas la réclamer.

Avec cette lettre je me permets de vous envoyer l'état de compte pour qu'il puisse être payé.

En terminant, cher monsieur, je me permets de vous offrir mes souhaits d'une heureuse et bonne année et vous prie de me croire,

Votre tout respectueux,

[Signature]

Revd.P.Bousquet,O.M.I.
Fort Alexandre.Man.

January 18th, 1926.

Mr. Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

Dear Sir:

I am taking the liberty of writing you about certain sums of money which were spent during the past Summer, at the school of Fort Alexandre, and which the Secretary of the Indian office refuses to refund under the pretext that they were never authorized. I am sure, Sir, that when you have read the present letter you will admit that my claim is quite legitimate.

In the month of November, 1924, the Indian office granted to our school one Deisel Machine operated with crude oil to develop electricity for our lighting. This machine arrived at Fort Alexandre only in the month of January and was installed during the course of last Summer by Brother Eug. Gauthier.

As it was understood with Mr. Graham, the school did not ask for any payment from the Government for the work performed by this Brother, but the school was obliged, however, to pay him the sum of one hundred and fifty ($150.00) dollars for his wages.

Now comes the difficulty. Who should pay for the material and the work of this installation? This machine being of a size and of a different
velocity to the old one, it was necessary to purchase new straps and fly wheels; who should pay for this? The Secretary of the Indian Office pretends that these expenditures were not authorized. As to myself, I am of a different opinion, as they were authorized by Mr. Graham directly or indirectly. This gentleman may have denied it to the Department, but I will try to demonstrate in a few words that he did so.

a/... Here is an extract of a letter received from Mr. Bunn, of Winnipeg, dated the 26th of November, 1924

Dear Sir,

Commissioner Graham of Regina was in my office a.m. to meet Revd. Brother Eug. Gauthier with reference to a new gasoline engine for your School lighting plant...I am enclosing herewith the blue print plans for the new foundation that will be required...You should provide ample quantities of sand, gravel and cement required for this, without any delay...."

This letter gives me orders from Mr. Graham through Mr. Bunn, of Winnipeg; and they are quite clear.

b/... Now let us look over the correspondence of the Commissioner himself.

Regina, February 5, 1925.

Dear Sir,

....I arranged with the Company to send a man down to see that the engine was properly installed, and I shall be glad if you will advise me if this was done....

Extract of another letter dated the 14th of February.

Dear Sir...... I gave instructions to have this engine installed when the purchase was made, and you not yet informed me whether the installation has been made or not....
In reading these different letters and others, alas, which I have not kept thinking that they would be useless, your representative at Regina has had the intention of giving orders and in fact gave such orders; and as to myself I only had to obey without any protest. Where was he taking himself the right to command? I always thought that he had them from Ottawa, and in the month of June I had the construction started, as I had told them during the month of February why I had to adjourn this work until a later date. Here are the explanations I was giving on this delay.

We have received the engines, but we don't work to put it in place. We are waiting for the nice season. There is a lot of cement work to be done, and buildings will have to be opened. It will not be wise to expose everything to freeze. Anyway we cannot get sand and stones in winter for foundations..."

As I told Mr. Graham in a letter accompanying the account for expenses which I forwarded to him during November last and of which I am sending a copy, the installation of these machines have needed a special house, as it was impossible to place them where the old ones were. "Mr. Bunn, as well as Mr. Christianson, can corroborate what I am saying here, as they have seen the place where the old machine was.) I will admit that the house that we have built is larger than was absolutely necessary for the electric machines; but it was made in provision of future need. If Mr. Scott is unable to grant the full amount, I would ask him to kindly grant us half of that sum, and later on when the remainder of the building will be used to put in the reservoirs, the Government should grant us the remainder...
as all the money which was paid for it belongs to the Congregation of the Oblate Fathers, and with their permission I have invested there my salary with a certain part of that of my assistant.

I have written you with confidence, Sir, describing the facts as they are. I regret to come back on this question of money, but the amount is such that I found I had to claim it.

With this letter I have taken the liberty of sending a statement of the account so that it might be settled.

In closing this letter I wish to offer my best wishes for a Happy New Year.

Yours, etc.,

Rev. P. Bousquet, O.M.I.

Dear Sir:

In reference to your letter of the 28th of January last, number 125-1-5.

I wish to thank you sincerely for the courtesy with which my letter of the 16th of January last was received, and in which I was claiming the sum of $1,338.66 which I spent for the installation of certain machinery at the School of Fort Alexandre. I have noticed with pleasure that you recognize my right of claiming immediately the money spent especially for the foundation of the new engine (5' X 7 X 8) and the exhaust tank (7' X 7 X 10) requested by the Company which furnished the engine. In all this it was necessary to have new iron fittings. Everything has been accomplished according to the orders of Mr. Bunn and Mr. Graham.

Furthermore, I did not believe it was necessary to have special authorization to get the necessary straps and new pulleys as the old ones could not be used with the new engine which has a velocity and flywheels completely different to the old one. It seems to me that all this was the consequence of the orders of Mr. Graham who was pressing the installation of the engine, so that everything should work alright.

The expenditure made to execute the work above mentioned has been over $700.00.

Concerning the building which was made to house these machines, I recognize now that I should have received explicit authorization. However, I consider that it was absolutely necessary. Today, more than ever, I see that I have done well in having it built, (notwithstanding my mistake in not obtaining the required permission), the fire protection we have is most deplorable. Very often our reservoirs are absolutely empty on account of leaks and other unavoidable reasons. However, they are too small for our
institutions, therefore, before we can put our new engine and the pump in action, it takes fifteen to twenty minutes; in case of fire this would be too long, the school would already be on fire.

It is, therefore, necessary that we should have reservoirs with pressure as soon as possible; the only place to put them would be in the cellar of this building I had built, but for which I should have obtained the necessary permission.

While asking you to kindly grant us for 1926-27 an adequate system to protect us against fire, I wish to ask you to grant us what you recognize to be due to us, that is to say about $700.00, awaiting that the remainder will be given to us in the next estimates of the Parliament.

C'est ce dernier tuyau qui est percé à l'intérieur du réservoir. Il faut absolument le remplacer parce que l'eau, venant de ce réservoir, nous remplit la grosse fournaise jusque dans les calorifères de la maison.

Comme ce réservoir pour les bains existe depuis bien des années, je crois qu'il serait prudent et sage de remplacer pareillement tous les tuyaux du serpentin, tout en remplaçant le tuyau aujourd'hui brisé ou percé; car ils doivent être très rouillés.

Sir,

I beg you to have certain repairs done in our heating system and the hot water tank for the Bath of the school.

Heating System: It is necessary to renew the grates in the fire pit of our large steam furnace, as two of them have fallen, being completely burnt; and four are so much twisted by the heat of the fire that they are no more serviceable.

Our steam furnace, heating the school was built by the Vulcan Iron Co. of Winnipeg. The grates are 4 ft. long and weigh about 100 lbs. each.

Hot Water Tank: The tank in which we heat the water for the baths needs repair. The water is heated by two different pipes, one coming from the small furnace especially built to heat the tank, and the other coming from the large steam furnace which is only utilized in Winter to heat the school. It is this last pipe which is leaking in the interior of the tank. It is absolutely necessary to replace it as the water from the tank runs into the large furnace and into the radiators of the building.

As the reservoir (or tank) for the baths has been in existence for a long time (many years) I believe it would be wise to replace all the pipe coils used when renewing the broken pipe, as they must be very rusty.

These two repairs need to be made without delay, as we cannot heat the water for the baths and we will need the large furnace as soon as cold weather sets in. It will be possible for us to place the grates in another, as soon as we get them, but we cannot get in the reservoir to replace the coils nor the broken pipes.

Dear Father Bousquet:

I have your letter of October 26th, with reference to your request for reimbursement on account of expenditure incurred in the erection of an outbuilding at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School. I have read your communication of the same date to the Secretary and I note that the building in question is erected on property that does not belong to the Department.

May I refer to your letter of January 16th, last, in which you base your claim for reimbursement on the fact that you believed you had authority from Mr. Commissioner Graham to erect the building. If you considered the Department was going to pay for this work, why did you not select a site on the school land? I cannot agree to the expenditure of public money on permanent improvements to private property.

Concerning the proposed installation of pressure tanks, I wish to point out that, in your letter of February 22nd, last, you state that it was necessary that you should have pressure tanks as soon as possible and that the only place to put them was in the cellar of the building you had erected. You had already placed the electric light plant in this building and the Department considered the action communicated to you in official letter of the 18th of October was the only course to take.

I note in your letter that you believe it unwise to install pressure tanks without renewing the pipe line to the school. If this is the case, it may be advisable to postpone the activity until the spring, when new piping could be laid.

I have been in correspondence with the Department of Health with reference to using the river water after the Pine Falls Pulp Mills are in operation. I have asked Mr. Inspector Bunn to make enquiries concerning the exact nature of the arrangements that are being made at the mill.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. Scott.

With reference to Inspector Bunn's letter of the 20th instant, hereunder, concerning the possible pollution of the water supply for the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, by the discharge of drainage and sewage from the Manitoba Paper Co.'s Mills at Pine Falls, I beg to say that considering the small amount of sulphuric acid which will empty into the Winnipeg River there will be no danger of the water being materially affected by this chemical. The explanation given by Mr. Irvine, General Manager of the Company, with regard to the chemicals which will be used in the operation of their plant is quite correct. As to the explanation given by this gentleman regarding the disposal of the sewage from the employees' toilets, I find it to be incomplete. The Department should be fully advised as to whether the sewage is to be treated before being discharged into the river. The Company should be compelled to submit plans showing the entire drainage and sewerage disposal systems to the Manitoba Department of Health for approval, and this Department should be advised as to the result of the investigation.

I would suggest as the surest way of ascertaining whether the water at the proposed intake of the water work system at the school site will be polluted that a frequent bacteriological analysis be made of it for some time, and this without considering the proposed type of sewerage system which might be adopted by the company. I will undertake to obtain the above mentioned information if you approve of my recommendation.

Sir:

Re Indian Residential School at Fort Alexander.

This will acknowledge your letter of February 2nd with reference to the request of the Department of Indian Affairs that an investigation be made of the water supply system of the Indian School and a report with estimates of cost of either providing a new system or of making the necessary repairs and alterations to the existing one.

The matter was taken up with Mr. Bunn, Inspector of Indian Agencies at Winnipeg, and he stated that all he knew of the situation was from his correspondence with Father Bousquet, Principal of the School. From this correspondence it appears that it is not a question of the water supply system itself being unsatisfactory but the possible danger of contamination of the school's water supply from the waste and sewage from the Manitoba Paper Company's pulp mills at Pine Falls. This is due to the fact that the school takes its water from the Winnipeg river some eight miles below the pulp mills, the waste and sewage of which is discharged into the river. To determine whether Father Bousquet's fears are warranted and that the water supply of the school will be dangerously contaminated under the existing conditions will require an extensive investigation. This investigation will include the securing of numerous samples of the water at the point of supply and at different stages of the river, together with a chemical analysis of the same. Further, it will also be necessary that the investigation cover the summer months, as at this time the danger from contamination is most likely to occur.

At the present time only one paper machine is installed but according to reports a second is likely to be added in the near future. Mr. Irving, General Manager of the pulp mill, in a letter to Father Bousquet, a copy of which Mr. Bunn has on file, states that at present there are about 225 employees, which would be increased to 300 if the second machine was installed. This near prospect of a second machine will necessitate a further investigation when the mill is brought up to its full capacity.

In view of the fact that it does not appear to be a question of altering or repairing the water supply system of the school, but one of possible danger of
