REPORT ON
PRESENT AND PROPOSED
WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM.
FORT ALEXANDER INDIAN SCHOOL,
FORT ALEXANDER, MANITOBA.

WINNIPEG, MANITOBA.
MARCH, 1927. BY JOHN CRAIG.
In February, 1927, the Department of Indian Affairs requested that in view of reports that the water supply system in the Indian School at Fort Alexander was inadequate for present needs, an inspection of the system be made by engineers of this Branch and a report with estimates of costs submitted for a new system, if required, or if the present plant could be satisfactorily overhauled, the repairs and alterations necessary for the work. Under date of February 26th Mr. J. T. Johnston requested that this office make the necessary inspection and submit a report covering the points asked for by the Department of Indian Affairs.

The Fort Alexander Indian School, which is located on the south bank of the Winnipeg river some five miles below Pine falls, was visited on March 15th by the undersigned and Mr. E. B. Patterson, when the necessary inspection of the water system and survey of the grounds was made. In addition, the whole question was gone into fully with Rev. Father Bosquette, Principal of the school.

In the report which follows the necessary repairs or alterations for a system adequate for domestic purposes only and for one adequate for both domestic and fire purposes are treated separately. This method is followed in view of the fact that with a comparatively small outlay the present system could be put into a satisfactory condition for domestic purposes, whereas to make the system adequate for any sort of fire protection will mean numerous alterations and replacements with a corresponding relatively high outlay.
PRESENT WATER WORKS SYSTEM.

As shown on Plan No. 1 giving the general layout, the water supply for the school is taken from the Winnipeg river and the present system, outside of a few additions to the distribution system and some replacements, is the same as that originally installed in 1902 at the time the school was constructed.

The intake pipe running from the pump house into the river is a 2" galvanized iron pipe, 100' being laid on the shore and the remaining 350' in the river. It will be noted from Plan No. 2 that the water end of the intake is partly laid in an excavated trench until it reaches the deep water where it is supported on a timber trestle, the water at this point being about 25' deep. It was necessary, Father Bocquette stated, to extend the intake pipe out this distance in order to reach the main current of the river, some distance from the shore, owing to the water in the small bay being comparatively shallow. In 1918, owing to damage by frost, 350' of intake laid in the river was replaced so that this portion of the intake is about nine years old. The remaining portion of the intake on the shore is 24 years old, being laid in 1892.

On Plan No. 3 is shown the pumping unit, which is located in the basement of a building which includes, in addition to the powerhouse, a carpenter shop and space for storage purposes. The pump, which is a small plunger pump, has a capacity of 1,300 U.S. Gallons per hour against a head of 15 feet, built by the H. H. Myers & Co., Ltd., and installed in 1918, replacing a similar pump installed in 1902.
intake. Power for the pump is supplied by a belt drive from a 15 h.p. Semi-Diesel engine located on the ground floor of the power house. This engine, which was installed last year, also supplies power for a 7½ k.w. generator for lighting purposes. Though the rated capacity of the pump is 1,800 U.S. gallons per hour, actually this is largely reduced by the high lift, which at low water will be 22 feet and by the friction losses through the 450' of 2" intake pipe, the capacity of the pump will probably not run over 15 U.S. gallons per minute.

From the pump the water is carried through a 2" discharge main to the school building and thence to four storage tanks located in the attic of the school. Three of these tanks are made of galvanized iron 5' 9" diameter and 4' deep, the fourth being a square wooden tank, the dimensions being 5' 3" by 7' 6" by 3' deep. Of these tanks, which are all 24 years old, the wooden tank has been unserviceable for five years and of the circular tanks one has been out of service for the past month due to leakage. Of the two tanks now being used, these have been kept in use by placing about two inches of concrete in the bottom in the endeavor to stop leakage and make them serviceable.

In addition to the 2" force main from the pump house to the school a 1-1/4" pipe runs from the pump house to the Mission House and a 1" pipe from the school to the stable. Of these pipes the 2" and 1-1/4" were laid in 1902, while that from the school to the stable was laid by Father Bosquette himself 10 or 12 years ago. Due to the ground being frozen the condition of the piping was not ascertained, but from what Father Bosquette states the condition the intake pipe was in when replaced, and from a general knowledge of the
subject, it is more than probable that the pipes have served their time.

As shown on the general lay-out plan No. 1, the sewerage leaves the shore a short distance below the intake pipe. As, however, the intake runs some 350' out into the main current and as no trouble has occurred during the 24 years it has been operating, there is evidently no danger of contamination from this source.

DOMESTIC SERVICE ONLY.

In taking up the question of water supply for domestic needs Father Besquette stated that the present system as originally installed gives adequate service for the needs of the school. In view of the above, if the Department of Indian Affairs does not desire a certain amount of fire protection, it will only be necessary to put the present system into satisfactory working order by certain replacements. The pump itself should be good for many more years of service and though due to the high lift and large friction losses in the 450' of 2" intake it does not deliver its rated capacity, this simply means that the time required for the actual pumping each day is increased. In recommending the replacements considered necessary to put the system in proper working order for domestic supply it is assumed that the service pipes laid in 1902 are in poor condition and should be renewed. This can only, however, be definitely determined by an inspection of the pipes when uncovered. The replacements recommended are as follows.

Service Pipes.

100' of 2" intake pipe from shore to pump house.
270' of 2" pipe from pump house to school.
120' of 1-1/4" pipe from pump house to Mission House.
The above should also possibly include replacing of the 1" service pipe from the school to the stable by a 1½" pipe, as Father Bosquette states the present size gives poor service.

Storage Tanks.

The four storage tanks located in the school attic should be scrapped and replaced by four tanks similar to the circular tanks now in use. By having four tanks in service a certain amount of storage is available as a reserve in case of a temporary break-down of the pumping plant and the water requirements for the day can probably be supplied by one period of pumping.

In the attached estimates of costs for these replacements, the replacing of the 1" service pipe from the school to the stable by 1½" pipe is included, but as the cost of each replacement is given as a separate item the total cost excluding this item can readily be ascertained.

COMBINED FIRE PROTECTION AND DOMESTIC USE.

The following recommendations for a water system suitable for both fire and domestic use assume that the Department of Indian Affairs would not consider the replacing with a larger engine the present Semi-Diesel engine which was installed last year. This engine is 15 h.p. and as it is considered essential that light should be available in case of fire it is necessary to allow at least 5 h.p. for driving the fire equipment leaving 10 h.p. for pumping purposes. The engine should not be overloaded for a short time, as suggested.
With the above in view there is therefore 10 h.p. available for pumping purposes, which will allow a pump with a capacity of 30 Imperial gallons per minute against 100 pounds pressure and this size of pump is therefore recommended. Due to the high lift on the suction end a centrifugal pump would not be suitable and therefore a plunger type of pump is necessary. It is therefore proposed that this pump would replace the present small pump now in use and, as shown on Plan No. 3, be set in the same location and similarly driven by a belt from the present line shaft.

Intake

With a pump of the capacity recommended the size of the intake pipe, in order to reduce the loss of head through friction to a permissible amount, will have to be increased. It is proposed that the 100' section from the pump house to the river be 4" wrought iron and the 350' in the water be 5" wrought iron. This size is necessary as with the maximum lift on the suction side of 22' very little can be allowed for loss of head through friction. The proposed pipe would be laid the same as the present one, part of the latter section being laid in an excavated trench.

Pressure Tanks

For fire protection either a storage tank at an elevation that will give sufficient pressure, or pneumatic pressure tanks are necessary. Even with a quick starting engine it would be advisable, but in view of the slow rate of rise of the Semi-Diesel type now installed it is considered that the cost of an elevated tank high enough to give sufficient pressure for fire purposes would exceed the value of the water works, it is proposed to install the...
4' by 16' pneumatic pressure tanks in the basement of the power house, as shown on Plan No. 3. These tanks would be connected in parallel and any one or all could be used at the same time. As it takes 20 minutes to start with the present type of engine, it will be necessary if proper fire protection is to be available, that two of the pressure tanks be kept at 100 pounds pressure, the third tank being used for domestic purposes. In case of fire the valves of the two reserve tanks at 100 pounds pressure could then be opened and water at a sufficient pressure would be available until the pump was put in operation.

Distribution Mains.

To take care of the increased capacity of the pump for fire protection it will be necessary to replace the present 2" pipe from the pump house to the school by a 3". In addition, it will be advisable, in order to provide a certain amount of fire protection for the stables, to have the 1" pipe already laid from the school to the stables replaced by a 2", and the 1-1/4" pipe from the power house to the Mission House replaced by new pipe of the same size.

In preparing the estimates of cost for combined fire protection and domestic service the cost of replacing the 1" pipe from the school to the stable is placed as a separate item, the total cost exclusive of this work being thus given.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Scott,

With reference to my memorandum of the 24th of January regarding the necessity of carrying out certain repairs to the water supply system at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, we have today received a report from the Dominion Water Power Branch and they recommend that either the present system can be repaired and put in good working condition, the cost of which will be approximately $1,700.00, or a new and more elaborate system installed for $6,439.00. The first price includes the repairs necessary to the pipeline and renewing the storage tanks now located in the top story of the school. In view of the fact that we have no place to install the pneumatic tanks and Father Bousquet, the Principal, has stated to the Engineer of the Dominion Water Power Branch that he would be satisfied if the present system is put in good working order, I would recommend that the necessary repairs required to the existing system, together with the renewing of the storage tanks be authorized.

In this room 32 children were present, ranging from grade 3 to 6.

The children appeared well along in their work and were not afraid to speak out when reading or answering questions. I see no reason why more advanced work should not be undertaken, especially up to grade 8, although, from what I could learn, work has only been carried on up to and including grade 6.

This classroom is very large and will accommodate 60 pupils. The room is well lighted and well supplied with blackboard room. The books and all the furniture were in excellent condition and one feels that the best of care is given things in general. The children were clean and very tidy.

The junior classroom is in charge of Sister Philip Marie who had 30 present. This room is smaller than the senior room, yet accommodates the pupils nicely. Here, again, the children were clean and very tidy. The school work heard was good and I have no doubt the children are making progress. The attendance in both rooms, according to the register, is excellent.

The dormitories were all spotless and the beds beautifully made and clean. In fact, the whole school was in excellent condition and all the departments appeared to be under good management.

I spent considerable time going over the fire equipment. I found all the doors on the last wing built, which lead to the fire escape, all open inward. The first door opens in and allows one to enter a hallway about 8 ft. square, then another door opens from this on to the fire escape and this door also opens inward, so that there are two doors on each of the three floors and all open.

Actg. D.S.G.I.A.

Contamination of water supply

Fort Alexander Reserve.

The Manitoba Pulp & Paper Co. discharge sewerage from their mill and town of Pine Falls into the Winnipeg River at a point immediately above the Fort Alexander Reserve, and as the river is the sole source of water supply that the Indians have, and as both the Catholic Boarding School and the Anglican day school also use the river, there is a grave risk of a typhoid epidemic starting unless some action is taken to obviate this contamination.

The situation is particularly aggravated when a west wind blows in from the Lake, (the prevailing wind) as this tends to back up the water in the river, and causes the sewage to collect.

The remedy is either to insist on the mill company disposing of their sewage in another manner, or construct sufficient wells for the use of the Indians and the schools.

The mill and town draw their water supply from a point about 1 mile above the place where the sewage discharges, and they might consider a proposal to pipe sufficient good water from their mains so as to provide the Indians with ample for their use.

In my opinion, some prompt action is desirable before an epidemic starts.

H.J. Busy
Supervisor Indian Timber Lands.
Sir:

I beg to advise that complaints have been received regarding the contamination of the water in the Winnipeg River at the Fort Alexander Reserve, due to the action of the Manitoba Pulp & Paper Co., in depositing sewage from their mill and also from the town of Pine Falls, into the river at a point above the Indian houses and schools, and it appears that there is great risk of a typhoid epidemic breaking out if this practice is permitted to continue, without taking steps to counteract it.

The situation is aggravated by the fact that the prevailing wind which is from the west across Lake Winnipeg tends to back up the water in the river, thereby causing the deposited sewage to collect.

The Department is aware that you have recently taken steps to have samples of the water that is used by the schools and Indians, analysed, and I shall be pleased to be informed of the result of this examination.

In any event however, it is proposed to remedy the situation, as it will doubtless get worse rather than better, and there appears to be only three ways of dealing with it.

1. Insist on the company disposing of their sewage in another manner, than dumping it in the river.
2. Arrange for the construction of wells at various points on the reserve.
3. Have the company run two pipe lines along the river banks, so that these can be tapped at regular intervals.

As the company derive a pure supply of water from the river at a point some distance above their sewage outlet, they may be disposed to consider the last proposal, provided proper measures can be taken to see that the various outlets from the mines are not permitted to freeze up in the winter.

Kindly favor the Department with your own views in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

C.A. Stevenson Esq.,
Indian Agent
Selkirk, MAN.

Winnipeg, September 13th, 1928.

Dear E. D. Bissett,
Pine Falls,
Manitoba.

Dear Doctor,

In regard to the matter contained in communication from A. F. McKenzie of the Department of Indian Affairs to C. A. Stephenson, Indian Agent, Selkirk, Manitoba, a copy of which you left with me this morning, I may say that the position of the town of Pine Falls in regard to the adjacent country to the west down the river does not differ from the position or responsibility of any city or town in Manitoba which empties its sewage into the river on which it is located. The City of Brandon, the Town of Portage la Prairie, and the City of Winnipeg, all dispose of their sewage into the adjacent streams. It is inevitable, therefore, that the water below a town of any considerable size is bound to be impure, and the only way to meet this difficulty, or at least the way it is being met in other localities, is to put the responsibility of supplying pure water upon the local authorities; that is, upon the Department of Indian Affairs, in this instance, or local councils in organized territory.

The difficulty is usually met by digging wells to supply the local needs.

As to the past paragraph in this letter, in which it is stated that a supply of pure water is obtained from the river above the town of Pine Falls at some distance above the sewage outlet, it may be pointed out that the water of the Winnipeg River is liable to contamination at many points above Pine Falls, and that consequently there is a danger from drinking the water of the Winnipeg River at any point between its head and its outlet into Lake Winnipeg.

Believe me,
Yours sincerely,
E. W. Montgomery,
Minister of Health,

INDUSTRIAL TYPE WATER SOFTENER

REFINITE

Why Water Supplies are Hard

Hardness in water is caused mostly by the salts of Calcium (Lime) and Magnesium as Bicarbonates, Sulphates or Chlorides.

How Hardness is Removed from the Water

The Zeolite or base exchange process of Water Softening will reduce the hardness to Zero. In passing water containing Hardness through a bed of Refinite Mineral, the Hardness Forming Salts are exchanged for Sodium, leaving the water perfectly softened.

WATER EQUIPMENT LIMITED
TORONTO, CANADA
The reaction may be described as follows:

Calcium Bicarbonate plus Sodium REFINITE forms Calcium REFINITE plus sodium Bicarbonate

OR

Ca(HCO₃)₂ plus Na₂REFINITE forms CaREFINITE plus 2Na HCO₃

It will thus be seen that as the water is being softened the Hardness Forming Salts become part of the Refinite Mineral bed and the softened water carries nothing to destroy soap or deposit scale in boilers. The other Hardness Forming Salts exchange for the Sodium in the same manner.

To regenerate the Softening bed when it has softened its full capacity a solution of Sodium Chloride (Common Salt) is passed through it and the Hardness Forming Salts are removed from the Refinite mineral and washed to the drain. The reaction is shown below:

CaREFINITE plus 2NaCL forms Na₂REFINITE plus CaCL₂

Why Water is Softened

The uses of Softened Water are many and varied. Laundries save one-third to more than one-half of their washroom supplies and turn out finished work which is impossible with unsoftened water. Textile mills save soap, soda, dyes and improve their products and the price they get for them. Power plants everywhere eliminate scale in their boilers and the other hard water troubles. The benefits of eliminating the hardness forming salts from water in industries and institutions are now so well known that further comment is unnecessary.

Description of Industrial Type Water Softeners

Water Softeners using REFINITE have been in satisfactory use in the largest laundries, industries, hotels and institutions in Canada for years.

REFINITE RAPID REGENERATING MINERAL is the same material that has during the last ten years proven itself capable of delivering high softening rates and larger capacities between regenerations without disintegrating and without discoloring the water.

The Industrial Type REFINITE SOFTENER shown consists of a steel tank welded or riveted with man-hole and inlet and outlet connections for the hard and soft water lines. The tank is ordinarily built to withstand a working pressure of 67 pounds per square inch but can be built to meet any requirements.

The salt tank is of steel of sufficient size to hold the salt required for each regeneration.

All pipes valves and fittings to connect the softener tank and the salt tank are furnished as shown. The purchaser only needs to connect his hard water line and softened water line and furnish sewer connections to complete his piping before commencing operation.

Where steam is available a steam ejector is used to circulate the water in the softener through the salt tank dissolving the salt and as the brine passes through the REFINITE bed it completely removes the hardness forming salts that were taken from the water which has been softened.
In the lower part of the Softener tank an under drain and collector system of special bronze strainers connected to the inlet or hard water line allows the water when softening to pass uniformly UPWARDS through a shallow bed of specially selected silica gravel which acts as a further diffuser and causes the water to rise evenly through the REFINITE mineral which rests on the gravel and fills the balance of the space in the Softener tank to a point near the outlet at the top.

The gravel and REFINITE are shipped in bags ready for putting in the Softener Tank.

A meter to measure the water softened is furnished and where required we furnish a special contact bell-ringing attachment which draws the operator's attention when the full capacity of the softener has been used and regeneration is necessary.

Regeneration consists of dissolving the salt in the brine tank and forcing it several times through the bed of REFINITE mineral by means of the steam ejector, or when steam is not available, circulating it with a bronze pump connected to a motor. Regeneration of the mineral is complete in thirty minutes.

Selection of Sizes

To determine the correct equipment for any given conditions an analysis of the water is the first requirement. Iron or suspended matter in any considerable quantity must be removed before the water is passed through the bed of Refinite as the pores of the Mineral can be clogged so that it will no longer function. Iron removal and Sand Filters may be necessary in such a case. It may be that other treatment than the Zeolite treatment is required. Information as to what the treated water is to be used for is desirable. The maximum amount of water required to be treated per minute and per hour should be stated. Decide how often it will be convenient to regenerate the Softener. Where a continuous supply of softened water is required and no storage is available, a two unit plant may be preferred.

Why Refinite is Best

1. Upward flow when Softening.
2. No Back-washing.
3. Low pressure loss throughout the Softening run.
4. Less floor space.
5. Heavier and larger Mineral grains.
6. Smaller tanks.
7. Economical operation, less water and salt for regeneration.
8. Softeners installed 10 years ago are operating the same today.
9. Does not turn the water green or brown.

GENERAL DESCRIPTION

Standard Pressure Filters are built for 67 pounds working pressure per square inch and tested to 100 pounds. The filtering materials are specially selected and graded silica sand and gravel.

Valves and fittings 3 inches and smaller are screwed pattern, 4 inch and larger are flanged.

The water enters the filter at the top and is deflected by a baffle plate so that the filter bed is not disturbed. It then passes downward uniformly through the filter bed and is collected in a piping system covering the entire bottom of the filter, and passes to the outlet.

The suspended matter which it is desired to filter from the water collects on the upper portion of the filter bed and when sufficient has collected to cause a loss of pressure of 5 pounds the filter must be cleaned, which is accomplished by reversing the flow of water and washing upward through the filter and out at the top to the waste.

The use of a Coagulant is essential with a Pressure Sand Filter. If it is desired to remove all suspended matter visible to the naked eye. This Coagulant usually Ammonium Aluminum Sulphate, commonly called Alum, is introduced to the water by means of the Pressure Coagulant Feeder which consists of an iron container with the necessary valves, pipes and fittings to allow a small portion of the water going to the filter to be bypassed around it and run back to the inlet line of the filter carrying a small amount of Alum in solution. When the water contains sufficient alkalinity, this minute amount of Alum produces Hydrate of Alumina, a sticky gelatinous substance which brings the impurities in the water together into large particles and thus is unable to pass the top of the filter bed.

In the case of swimming pools or natural water supplies having very little alkalinity, an additional Pressure Chemical Feeder, similar to the Alum Feeder should be used to introduce small amounts of Soda Ash, or some such chemical, to the water.

It is important that the filter be back-washed when necessary and that sufficient water be available for this purpose. Care should be taken by the operator, when backwashing, that he does not exceed the rate of 15 gallons per square foot per minute and thus wash sand out to the sewer and possibly disturb the filter bed, also that he does not waste water by endeavoring to wash at too slow a rate.

Description of the Super-Turbine Pump

Perfected to meet the insistent demand for an absolutely dependable pump of this general type capable of delivering against high pressures in continuous operation. It represents the greatest forward stride in pump design and manufacture that has been accomplished in years. It has no pistons, valves, gears, cams, springs, belt, idler, flywheel or coupling. There is only one moving part in the pump.

Only the best of materials are used. The impeller, raceway, discharge and intake castings are of high grade bronze. The impeller and end ring through the motor and pump is of special non-corrosive, Stainless Steel and is rust-proof. Water in passing through the pump does not come in contact with any corrosive material at any point.

It is especially adapted for use in all general pumping service and for home water supply in connection with pneumatic storage tanks.

Suction—The Super-Turbine Pump will handle water on a gravity suction lift as any pump. Actual tests have been made pumping water from more than 30 feet vertical lift. However, experience with all types of pumps has shown it best to mount a liberal factor of safety to compensate for small leaks, air pockets, friction, etc., in suction lines; therefore we recommend that the vertical distance of pump above water level does not exceed 25 feet.

Air—The Super-Turbine Pump will not only handle enough air to insure its satisfactory performance under fluctuating conditions but also the simple operation of an air valve in the suction line will supply whatever air is required for the hydro-pneumatic tank.

Pressure—The pumping of water is accomplished by the rotation of the impeller "A" in the direction indicated by the arrows, the impeller buckets catching the water and forcibly discharging it into the raceway. The action of the impeller buckets upon the water as it flows through the raceway, which action is found only in the Super-Turbine Pump, makes it possible to attain more than double the normal pressure desirable for the average water system.

Characteristics—The impeller takes up its load gradually as the motor accelerates, therefore the starting current required is scarcely more than is required for the horse-power, or about half as great as required by any other type of pump. The volume of water delivered is increased as the pressure decreases, thereby supplying a larger stream when essential, and also tending to maintain an even load on the motor.

Super-Turbine Pumps will not pound or hammer under any condition of operation.

Efficiency—The races of the stationary raceway and rotating impellers, including the sealing rings "C" which surround them, match each other so perfectly and may be so easily and accurately adjusted with reference to each other that the efficiency is higher than ever before attained in pumps of similar capacity.

Durability—Up to this time a durability test of over five years duration has definitely shown that the Super-Turbine Pump will, without repair, last longer than any other pump. A Figure 306 continuous shop operation pump, against 30 lbs. pressure, delivered over 4,875,000 gallons of water in 30 months. At the end of 30 months, this pump was disassembled and a thorough examination made by our engineers. Its condition was found to be so good that the identical pump was re-assembled and the test continued. At this time it has delivered over 150,000 gallons of water, as well as water as a family of four, using 50 gallons each per day, would need in 120 years, and during the entire period has received no attention except from an occasional oiling of the thrust or bearing surfaces.

Continuous Operation—All Super-Turbine Pumps herein listed are suitable for continuous operation against a maximum head of 115 ft. or 50 lbs. pressure per square inch.

Adjustment—The pump is so designed as to make it possible to adjust the clearance between impeller and raceway independent of accuracy of machine work or thickness of gasket, this feature being found only in this pump. The movable lower raceway ball bearing "E" is securely locked to the shaft, and by means of the adjusting nuts "F", the exact location of the impeller with reference to the raceway is maintained with accuracy. The original adjustment is made with the pump operating under pressure, and durability tests have indicated that it will never be necessary to change it.

Alignment—Motor and pump are mounted on opposite ends of a common base frame. The extended motor shaft is of special non-corrosive steel in one piece with the impeller securely locked upon it. The rotating parts are so perfectly centered and aligned that vibration is avoided and are so rigidly supported that the alignment cannot be disturbed. The result is a rigid compact assembly requiring no maintenance or readjusting, nor is there more than is required for the motor alone.

Mounting—The pump and motor assembly is substantially mounted on cast iron base and securely fastened by bolts at three points of contact, so that it cannot be thrown out of alignment by ordinary rough handling or by base being unevenly bolted to foundation.

Adaptability—Having no valves and but one moving part, the Super-Turbine Pump is the last word in pumps adaptable to any pumping duty. It is especially suitable for handling hot water, brine, alcohol, light oils, etc. It is equaled by no other pump in ensuring continuous trouble-free dependable service over a period of years. No expense has been spared to make it the best money can buy. It is "built to wear without repair" and will truly render "a life time of service."

THE Vacuum Type MSV chlorinator represents an entirely new principle in chlorine control. Its sturdy construction without small delicate parts makes it in keeping with the usual equipment found about a water works plant. Its design is such that the chlorine gas from the time it enters the apparatus until it is made into chlorine solution is always under a vacuum so that the possibility of leaks is reduced to a minimum. Furthermore, the flow of chlorine automatically ceases whenever the water supply to the apparatus is shut off. It is exceedingly simple to operate.

The chlorine is controlled by the vac-
vacuum produced by an auxiliary supply of water flowing through an injector. This vacuum draws the chlorine into the injector where it is mixed with the auxiliary water supply. The chlorine solution thus formed is conveyed to the water supply which is to be chlorinated.

The auxiliary water supply first passes through a strainer and then through a reducing valve to the injector (see drawing). The suction created by the water passing through the injector is transmitted through a silver adjustable head tube to the inside of a glass bell jar which stands in a partly filled tray of water. The vacuum created causes the level of the water inside the bell jar to rise above the water level outside the jar. This opens a float reducing valve which allows the chlorine to enter the bell jar, the chlorine cylinder being connected directly to the feed line to which this float valve is attached.

A glass meter tube with a calibrated orifice at the top fits over the silver adjustable head tube. Connection through several small ports is made from the inside of the meter tube to the inside of the bell jar so that normally water levels in both would be equal. The only way that the chlorine can enter the injector is through the orifice at the top of the meter tube and down through the silver tube. Since the flow of gas through an orifice depends on the drop in pressure across the orifice, it is only necessary to measure this drop to know the flow of gas at any time. The water level inside the meter tube can be adjusted by varying the elevation of the adjustable head tube inside the meter and the chlorine flow regulated in this manner. The pressure drop across the orifice is equal to the difference in height of the water inside the bell jar and inside the meter tube. The orifice meter tube is empirically calibrated to convert this difference to pounds of chlorine per twenty-four hours. A ratchet arrangement enables the adjustable head tube to be set as desired.

The chlorine then goes down into the injector where it mixes thoroughly with the water and then passes to the point of application through the discharge line.

Applicabilities

When the Vacuum type chlorinator is used to apply chlorine in a suction well, a clear water well or any other open body of water, it is known as our Type MSV. If the point of application is in a main, an additional connection to the main is necessary and we designate this as Type MSVM, it being identical with the MSV except for this additional connection.

To operate the Vacuum type chlorinator, the auxiliary water supply must be under at least 25 lbs. per square inch pressure in quantities of 50 gallons of water for each pound of chlorine.

The apparatus has a range of 4 to 1 for any orifice. By the use of various sized orifices the range of the machine can be varied as desired. The minimum capacity of the apparatus is one pound of chlorine gas per 24 hours, ordinarily sufficient to treat 150,000 to 200,000 gallons of water. The maximum capacity for the standard
type machine is 300 pounds of chlorine per 24 hours. Certain changes are necessary on the water supply and chlorine lines as the capacity increases. The apparatus should be housed to protect it properly against the elements and the temperature in the room in which it operates should never fall below 50° F.

Usually this type chlorinator is suitable for filter plants where the application can be conveniently made in the clear water well and at pumping stations and similar points where an auxiliary water supply is available. In the case of pumping stations, the auxiliary water supply can be taken from the pump discharge line. On large installations we also recommend it for gravity supplies even if no auxiliary water supply is available, installing an electrically driven triplex pump to supply the necessary water supply to operate the chlorinator.

The machine is also applicable for the sanitation of swimming pools, particularly those of large capacity and for the disinfection of sewage. The largest chlorinating installation in the world consists of machines of this type at the Westerly Sewage Disposal Plant, Cleveland, Ohio.

Advantages

Simplicity of operation is the chief advantage of the Vacuum Type chlorinator. Small fragile parts have been eliminated and the frequent adjustment often necessary with these small parts, diaphragms and valves is avoided.

The apparatus is so designed that there are no moving mechanisms to get out of adjustment. Every part is readily accessible for inspection. The heavy pedestal on which the apparatus is mounted makes the equipment a self-contained unit requiring but approximately two square feet floor space.

The chlorine is measured under a vacuum and hence the possibility of leakage of chlorine is greatly reduced. Another point of importance is that the flow of chlorine stops immediately upon failure of the auxiliary water supply. With other types, should the water supply fail the chlorine would continue to flow and corrosion would result. With the Vacuum chlorinator, just as soon as the water ceases to flow through the injector, the vacuum is no longer produced and the chlorine stops flowing.

We have been able to retain the fundamental advantages in this unit that are to be found in all of our chlorinators. The entire apparatus is hydraulic in principle, it has no moving parts. If it operates at all, it operates correctly. A visible chlorine meter is used and you can see the chlorine flowing; the same high percentage of flow accuracy is guaranteed.

The W&T Chlorometer
The W&T Chlorometer has been developed for the automatic proportional application of relatively small quantities of chemicals in solution. Its use is principally indicated in the application of chlorine sterilizing solution to the sterilization of water.

While intended largely for small water supplies and for indoor swimming pools, it has a wide range of usefulness. Accurate, rugged, simple, fool-proof—it can be made absolutely automatic in operation, requiring no attention other than replenishing the supply of solution.

**Description of Equipment**

In the standard W&T Chlorometer, a three gallon bottle of W&T sterilizing solution is inverted on a porcelain base with a connected chamber in which the sterilizing solution is maintained at a constant level.

A disc with a series of holes or recesses at its periphery is revolved in the chamber by power obtained from the gear train of a water meter through which flows the water that is to be chlorinated. As the disc revolves, the holes at its edge become filled with sterilizing solution. Capillary attraction and surface tension keep this solution in the holes until they are subjected to suction from a small injector near the top of the chamber. The injector sucks the sterilizing solution out of each hole as it passes by, and introduces it into the water supply to be treated.

Sterilizing solution will be introduced into the water only when the disc is revolving. The disc will revolve only when the meter is running. The meter will run only when water is flowing. Automatic proportional application is therefore obtained.

As the water starts to flow, the disc starts to revolve and the sterilizing solution is introduced into the water to kill the microbes of disease. As the water stops—the meter stops—the disc stops—and the introduction of sterilizing solution ceases. The faster the water flows—the faster the disc revolves. The slower the water flows—the slower the disc revolves. The application of sterilizing solution is proportional at all times.

Perforated dosing discs of different capacities are available. To increase the rate of dosage in parts per million a larger capacity disc may be attached. It takes but a moment to change discs, and requires no tools.

When installed for use in connection with swimming pool recirculating systems, the W&T Chlorometer is usually connected to a bypass inserted in the discharge line from the filters supplying water to the pool.

**Applicabilities**

The W&T Chlorometer is particularly applicable to the small water supply, which is operated by automatic pumping systems. A single bottle of sterilizing solution will often suffice for a six months' period. Since the equipment is entirely automatic, all of the water pumped is sterilized and is delivered to the consumers free from microbes of disease.

Boats on the Great Lakes and other fresh waters use the chlorometer to advantage in sterilizing all water that is taken into the fresh water tanks. The positive automatic action of the chlorometer makes it impossible to introduce into the tanks any water that is not sterilized as long as any sterilizing solution remains in the bottle. Many of the boats on the Great Lakes are equipped with the W&T Chlorometer and it is superior to sterilizing devices which have been available heretofore.

Swimming Pools

Indoor swimming pools find in the W&T Chlorometer a device for which there has long been serious need. It requires no attention other than replenishing the supply of sterilizing solution. This takes but a few seconds. Users of the chlorometer who have previously had experience with other types of sterilizing equipment emphatically state that the chlorometer is far superior.

Fire Pumps

The W&T Chlorometer may be used with entire success as a standby unit for fire pumps. Many institutions, factories, etc., have auxiliary water supplies which are placed into use in case of fire. Heretofore it has always been a problem to satisfactorily sterilize these emergency water supplies to prevent the possibility of disease being transmitted. By installing a W&T Chlorometer in connection with the pumps on the emergency supply, these supplies are safeguarded.

The W&T Chlorometer may be used for the automatic proportional application of small quantities of any chemical solution. It is used for the introduction of copper sulphate to destroy algae, and of sulphuric acid to correct hydrogen ion concentration at water purification plants.

Bottling Works

Bottling works and milk stations find the chlorometer of service in sterilizing bottles before filling. The chlorometer in these cases is installed on the discharge of the wash water pump, the sterilizing solution being added to the wash water.

Summer Camps

Summer camps and hotels and other institutions operated for only a portion of the year will find the chlorometer particularly serviceable, since in leaving the installation at the close of the season it is only necessary to drain it. In the spring or summer, it may be again placed in operation merely by inserting a fresh bottle of sterilizing solution.

Specifications For W&T Chlorometer

CAPACITY.—The apparatus shall have a maximum capacity for treating —— gallons of water per twenty-four hours at a maximum rate of — parts of chlorine per million gallons of water.

AUTOMATIC CONTROL.—The apparatus shall be so designed that the application of sterilizing solution shall be in direct proportion to the rate of flow of water through the meter.

CONTROL PARTS.—The control parts shall be of non-corrodible materials especially adapted for the accurate control of sterilizing solution. They shall be easily accessible for inspection, particularly the revolving feed disc, solution take-off block and injector assembly.

WATER METER.—The chlorometer shall be equipped with a suitable water meter which shall be so arranged as to provide the motive power for operating the revolving feed disc.

TELESCOPIC FLEXIBLE DRIVE SHAFT.—A connecting shaft shall be provided to transmit the motive power from the water meter to the revolving feed disc. This shaft shall be made so as to be easily removable when necessary.

CONSTANT LEVEL CHAMBER.—The constant level chamber shall be made of non-corrodible material, having two compartments with communicating aperture between the two. One compartment of the chamber shall form the support for the solution container, and the other compartment the supply chamber for the revolving feed disc.

SOLUTION CONTAINER.—The apparatus shall be so designed that the glass bottle in which the sterilizing solution is shipped shall fit into the compartment of the chamber arranged for that purpose, and form the solution container.

OVERFLOW.—The constant level chamber shall be provided with an overflow to insure against too high a level in the constant level chamber.

STERILIZING SOLUTION LINE.—The sterilizing solution line shall be of special Chlorine resistant tubing.

INJECTOR ASSEMBLY.—The injector assembly shall be a self-contained unit and all parts which come in contact with sterilizing solution shall be of special resistant materials. The injector assembly shall consist of a double injector throat device for taking the solution from the revolving feed disc by means of the suction which the injector produces, and shall also be arranged so as to prevent water from backing into the constant level chamber should back pressure develop in the injector discharge line.

REVOLVING FEED DISC.—The revolving feed disc shall be of special composition, and shall be arranged with a series of peripheral openings for picking up the solution from the constant level chamber and supplying it to the injector throat.

SOLUTION TAKE-OFF BLOCK.—A solution take-off block shall be provided for removing the sterilizing solution from the peripheral holes in the revolving feed disc, and transferring this solution to the injector throat.

CONNECTION TO MAIN.—Whenever the sterilizing solution is applied to the water in a main, there shall be provided a suitable connection constructed of materials resistant to chlorine solution and so arranged as to be easily removed for inspection.

MOUNTING.—The entire apparatus shall be self-contained, and mounted on a cast iron base.

FINISH.—All bright parts of the apparatus shall be plated with silver, or with standard W&T finish and lacquered.

ACCURACY OF CHLOROMETER.—The chlorometer shall meter the sterilizing solution with a variation of not greater than four per cent from the true delivery of sterilizing solution on all flows within the working capacity of the apparatus.

GUARANTEE.—The apparatus shall be guaranteed against all inherent mechanical defects for a period of one year from date of shipment from factory, when operated in accordance with instructions accompanying shipment.

DIMENSIONS AND SHIPPING WEIGHT.—Overall length, 36"; overall width, 19"; overall height (with stand) to top of bottle, 51"; without stand 33"; net weight, 200 pounds; gross weight, packed for shipment, 320 pounds; shipping dimensions, 18.5 cubic feet (36" by 32" by 38").

In this equipment, a compensating valve maintains a constant flow of chlorine for any setting of the control valve, regardless of changes in temperature or pressure of the chlorine. Water supply lines to operate the equipment and chlorine solution lines from the apparatus to the point of application pass through the pipe stand on which the apparatus is mounted.

**DURABLE SANITARY FINISH** — A chlorinating apparatus is a symbol of sanitation and should look the part. Every part of a Paradon unit that can be is finished in white vitrified enamel. It is easily kept looking new. The operator has an incentive to take good care of the equipment.

**PARADON DB AND D TYPES**

In the Types DB and D equipment the amount of chlorine to be fed is set manually and the regulator valve of the apparatus maintains this feed within close limits. In the Type D equipment, which is for small flows of from .03 to 3 pounds of chlorine per day, a regulator maintains a constant pressure drop across a small variable orifice; a constant pressure device maintains a constant density of gas passing through this orifice and a small volumetric meter indicates the amount of gas being fed. In the larger Type DB equipment, which is for flows of from 1 to 300 or more pounds of chlorine per day, a regulator varies the pressure drop across a fixed orifice, a constant pressure device maintains a constant density of gas passing through this orifice and a manometer connected to either side of the orifice indicates the amount of gas flowing.

In the DB Type the chlorine may be delivered from the equipment as a dry gas and introduced directly through diffusing apparatus or a water injector may be included in the unit and the chlorine delivered from this injector, to the water or sewage to be treated. The D type applies the chlorine only as a dry gas.

**APPLICABILITIES—TYPE DB UNIT**

The range of capacities is from 1 to 300 pounds of chlorine per 24 hours. Larger units can be provided when necessary. It is adapted for the treatment of medium and large sized water supplies, 1,000,000 gallons per day and upwards, and for most sewage plants and large swimming pools. It is the best chlorinator on the market.
**Type DB**—Chlorine is applied as a dry gas into a gate chamber, reservoir or other open body. The diffuser must be submerged 4 feet.

**Type DBM**—Chlorine is applied as a dry gas into a main or other closed conduit under pressures not over 25 lbs. per square inch. No auxiliary water supply is necessary.

**Type DBI**—An injector type unit which introduces chlorine into a pump well, clear well, sewage channel or open body. Water under a pressure of at least 20 lbs. per square inch is necessary.

**Type DBMI**—An injector type unit which introduces chlorine into a closed conduit. Water under a pressure of 20 lbs. per square inch and three times the pressure to be introduced against, is necessary.

**Applicabilities—Type D Units**

This type is used for small flows. Its capacity is from .03 to 3 pounds of chlorine per 24 hours. It is suitable for small water supplies with rates of flow of from 10,000 to 250,000 gallons per day and for sewage flows up to 25,000 gallons per day. It only applies chlorine as dry gas.

**Type D**—Chlorine is applied as a dry gas into a gate chamber, reservoir or other open body. The diffuser must be submerged four feet.

**Type DM**—Chlorine is applied as a dry gas into a main or other closed conduit. This equipment will introduce small amounts of chlorine against pressures up to 25 pounds per square inch.

**Paradon Thermo Chlorinator**

This company realized that there was a distinct demand for a simple inexpensive and foolproof chlorinator for small water supplies, swimming pools and small sewage plants. Our Type T and TS Series Thermo Control Chlorinator was developed to meet just these requirements—the simplest and most inexpensive chlorinator now available.

Our Thermo Control Type Chlorinator is of Injector type. The chlorine cylinder is kept in a water bath. In as much as the temperature of water varies but slightly from day to day, the temperature of the chlorine remains practically constant—thus the chlorine pressure is kept constant and the usual chlorine pressure reducing and constant pressure devices are eliminated, thereby greatly simplifying construction.

The chlorine passes from the cylinder through a control valve and then into a glass bubbling type volumetric meter, from which chlorine is drawn into an injector, there mixed with an auxiliary water supply and the mixture of chlorine and water applied to the water or sewage to be chlorinated. Part of the auxiliary water supply operating the injector is used to keep a small amount of water circulating in the water bath.

The bubbling meter is enclosed in a glass cylinder which fills with water just as soon as the injector is in operation, due to the vacuum created by the injector. This water acts as a medium to make visible the bubbles of gas released from the meter. As soon as the injector ceases to operate, the vacuum inside of the glass cylinder is released and the water level drops to the level of the overflow of the water bath, unsealing the bottom of the glass cylinder.

Our types T and TS Series Chlorinators are also made to feed the chlorine gas direct, no injector being used. This type is particularly adapted for swimming pools.

**Applicabilities of T and TS Types**

The Thermo type unit is the simplest and best chlorinator available for small water supplies and small sewage plants including those of small municipalities, private estates, hotels, institutions, camps, industrial plants, canneries, boats, dairies, etc. Available for practically all swimming pools, indoors and outdoors.

**Type T**—It has a capacity of from .02 to 3 lbs. of chlorine per 24 hours. It is applicable for the smallest water supply up to a maximum rate of flow of about 200,000 gallons of water per day. It is also applicable for average pools up to 150,000 gallons per day and for small sewage plants up to 25,000 gallons rate of flow per 24 hours. The point of application is into a filter chest well, gate well or other open body. Water under at least 20 lbs. per square inch pressure is required for its operation. A 12 pound cylinder of liquid chlorine is used in the water bath.

**Type TM**—It is the same as the Type T except that the chlorine is applied into a main or other closed conduit. The water pressure for the injector should be at least three times the pressure existing at the point of application.

**Type TS**—It uses the same principle of operation as the Type T except that a 100 pound cylinder of chlorine is used in the water bath instead of a 12 pound cylinder. The capacity is from .02 to 10 lbs. of chlorine per 24 hours. It is applicable for the smallest water supply up to a maximum rate of flow of approximately 1,000,000 gallons per 24 hours. It is also suitable for practically all swimming pools and for sewage flows up to approximately 150,000 gallons per 24 hours. The point of application is into a main or other closed conduit, gate well, filter basin or any other open body of water. Twenty pounds per square inch water pressure is necessary for its operation.

**Type TSM**—It is the same as Type TS except that the point of application is into a main or other closed conduit. The point of application cannot be under a pressure greater than one third the pressure of the auxiliary water supply operating the injector.

Types T, TM, TS and TSM are also made to apply the chlorine gas direct using the improved Paradon diffuser. No water pressure is then necessary.

The gas is removed from the bubbler by means of an injector, in which the water comes in intimate contact with the chlorine and forms a sterilizing solution, which is fed to the point of application through rubber hose.

The outstanding mechanical feature of this machine lies in the fact that there are no compensating diaphragms to give trouble, the chlorine being kept at a constant temperature by means of a water bath.

Sir:-

When on my recent visit to the Fort Alexander Boarding School, the Principal asked me if the Department would consider providing the school with a potato parer. They ask for this on the ground that they have had a very poor crop of this vegetable this year, in fact only one half the quantity required for one year's supply, and that the use of a parer will enable them to effect a saving. The request is somewhat unusual, but I was satisfied with the condition of and administration at this school, and sometimes it is politic to encourage school authorities who take an interest in the welfare of the children over whom they have supervision. The cost will be a very small one. Will you please advise me if the purchase can be made.

Dear Mr. Scott:-

On the occasion of my recent visit to the Fort Alexander School I found the floors which the fire escape poles run through surrounded by a trap door with a hasp, staple and padlock on, and the key in the possession of the Brother, which means that if the Brother was away from the building and the fire alarm rang, everyone would rush to the fire escape and pile up and it would be a very serious situation.

I have instructed the Principal to take the padlock off at once. Of course, there is the usual argument that the boys can escape, or that someone can come into the dormitories, but I told them this could not be helped in the meantime.

I would suggest, however, that in the dormitories where there are fire escapes we partition off sleeping quarters for a member of staff, so that in order to get access to or from the fire escape it would be necessary to pass through these sleeping quarters. This is the only solution of the problem in my opinion. It would cost some hundreds of dollars to have this done, but it should be done without delay.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Re: Ft. Alexander Mission Chlorometer.

The chlorometer equipment at the Mission was inspected by Mr. Lindsten of the Wallace & Tierman Co. Winnipeg office, Mr. Turner and myself on Dec. 13th.

We found the following conditions:

(1.) Water strainer on water supply to chlorometer plugged with dirt and fish.
(2) Sterilizing Solution in use too weak and old.

Mr. Lindsten recommended the supply line to chlorometer be changed from ¼" to ½" pipe. We have had this made up in the mill. It is about one foot long and in addition we have had an extra strainer installed in this new line using 80 mesh bronze wire.

The simpler we can make the operation of this chlorometer installation the better and I will give the attendant there as complete data and instructions as possible so he can keep the machine always in good order. Mr. Lindsten advised regular inspections and tests on the water both by orthotolidin for residual chlorine and bacteriological tests.

We took samples of both the raw and "Chlorinated" water on this visit and these have been turned over to Dr. Bissett. Although we do not expect the "Chlorinated" water to be good on account of the weak sterilizing solution, the sample was taken as usual.

We arranged with Mr. Lindsten to have a fresh 10% sterilizing solution sent here at once and he also promised to send me the formula so I can make up the solution in the Lab. hereafter.

While Mr. Lindsten was here an inspection was also made of the town chlorinator and he pronounced everything in first class condition except one small assembly which was worn and should be replaced. This has been requisitioned and Mr. Lindsten is sending out the parts at once.

cc Mr. Bissett

Chief Chemist
Fort Alexander Mission School - Water Chlorometer.

Complaint was received Jan. 5th that the water at the Mission School was too strong in chlorine.

An inspection visit was made January 8th and the machine was found to be working satisfactorily, but the fault of too much chlorine was due to a misunderstanding of the written instructions left with the operator on the last inspection. This was clearly explained to the operator and also to the Father in Charge so that no further complaint on this point is anticipated unless the instructions are disregarded. Two samples of water were taken and turned over to Dr. Bissett for examination. Extra carboy was brought back to Pine Falls so that new solution can be prepared in readiness for change when it becomes necessary.

cc. MF.C.C. Irvine
MF.J.F. Thibedeau
MF.H.W. Turner
DF.E.D.R. Bissett

Would you please let me know your findings on this water when complete.

Re: Fox Alexander Chlorinating System.

You will recall that some time ago, we arranged to have an inspection made of this equipment, periodically, and this has been done on average of once a month. Dear Sir:

I am pleased to inform you that I made up my mind to take the two water tanks of 1250 gallons each costing $690.00, expenses of installing and transportation included exceeding therefore the Department grant by $190.00. I have been hesitating for a long time before assuming that heavy debt in that hard times when the school can hardly meet its current expenses. But the consideration of the great advantage to have water tanks for the school of such capacity to hold a sufficient supply of water for one day, eliminating the trouble and expenses of pumping more frequently than once a day, has determined me to make my choice.

Sir:-

This work should be carried out at once, and I shall be glad to know if the Department approve of placing the order with the Standard Plumbing & Heating Co. Ltd., on the distinct understanding that $500.00 will be paid by the Department and the balance by the Principal of the school.

My dear Doctor:

Please accept my very sincerest thanks for your letter of the 21st instant in which you inform me that you have had an order placed for the Laundry Machinery for the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School.

I have already informed Reverend Father Perreault, the principal, of his good fortune and he asked me to convey to you his warmest personal thanks.

However this Laundry question is giving Father Perreault considerable worry and, being of a nervous temperament, he is rather anxious to know what should be done about the installation of the machinery.

I believe your Mr. Hamilton has already informed your Department that the building in which it is proposed to install the new machines is in such a condition that rather substantial repairs are most urgent. This building was at one time used as a laundry and it was built for that purpose by the Department. But the contractors made a very poor job of it, with the result that the foundation, the cement floor and almost the whole of the walls, (the building is of frame construction), have to be completely rebuilt. The material alone for this work would cost over $900. The T. Eaton Co. submitted the lowest figure. Their price f.o.b. Pine Falls is $957.21. It is likely that an amount equal to that will have to be spent by the School for labor but we are willing to undertake that and provide the money from our general Missionary Fund.

Sir:

I deem it my duty to call your attention to the insufficient fire protection now enjoyed by the school. As you know, the Fort Alexander School is a frame building. There is no fire protection of any kind outside of the building, so that, if at any time there is a fire, the only method of fighting it would be with buckets. The staff maintained by the school would be insufficient in number to organize a proper brigade, and I feel sure that, under almost any circumstances, the school would become an easy prey to the flames.

I have taken this matter up with our engineer, and he suggests installing two hydrants - one on each side of the building - both to be equipped with a sufficient quantity of fire hose, say, of 1½" dimension, to reach both ends of the building at the same time.

What has been said of the school itself holds, although to a less degree, for the outbuildings, principally the stable and cow barn. A smaller quantity of hose, of course, would be required for protection in this latter case.

As Indian schools are not insured and as the Government finds it extremely difficult to provide funds for rebuilding such schools as are destroyed by fire, I am of the opinion that the matter of fire protection should be attended to more strictly than it has been up to date.

Hoping that you will give due consideration to my request, I remain,

Yours very truly,

S. Perrault,
O. M. I.,
Principal.

November 15, 1934

Mr. C. C. Irvine  
Manager

Following your instructions I visited the Indian Mission at Fort Alexander on the afternoon of November 12th, made a careful inspection of their chlorinating system and beg to report as follows:

When I arrived, the chlorine system was not being used, the meter and chlorine feeder were by-passed. I examined all parts carefully to learn if any were in a condition to warrant renewal, but except for some corrosion I could see no reason why it should not operate satisfactory.

The valves were then opened and by-pass closed; the injector water and solution inlet to pump suction opened to put feeder in motion. I made one or two slight adjustments, and except that the regulating water was a little slow in filling float chamber, the reason no doubt being a dirty filter, everything worked alright.

I would suggest that this feeder be given a thorough cleaning, the filter and strainer in the injector water line be opened up, and filling renewed. Samples of water taken at least once a week and tested for available chlorine so that proper feeding adjustments can be set to maintain safe chlorination. That some person around the plant be instructed in the working of the machine, and be made responsible for its maintenance and operation.

The equipment if properly operated and maintained, if ideal for a service of this nature.

Wm. Bird.

Dear Mr. Gow:

With reference to your request re supply of power to Fort Alexander Indian Reserve Mission:

On the basis of the distance being six miles, the road being reasonably straight, and a maximum load of 50 kilowatts at 80% power factor, three phase, 2200 volts, being taken, I would recommend that this line be built using No. 2 Aluminum Cable Steel Reinforced, on 30 ft. poles spaced 200 ft. apart, the separation of the wires being 18 inches.

On the assumption that good poles can be cut locally and supplied on the job for not more than $2.00 a piece, and that the work can be done by local labor, I would estimate this line to cost approximately $4,500.00. This is on the assumption that there are not too many curves or anchors required, and does not include cost of clearing.

In addition to the above there will be required transformers and fuses at the receiving end; the transformers would cost approximately $120.00 each and the cutouts $50.00.

I have estimated labor costs on this line at $200.00 a mile, or a total of $1,200.00.

The size of conductor given would give a reasonable regulation and would be sufficiently strong mechanically to take care of weather conditions.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) "E. V. Caton",
Manager, Electric Utility.

August 7, 1925.

Sir:

In accordance with the request contained in your letter of July 17th with reference to the supplying of hydro-electric power to the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, the writer proceeded to Fort Alexander and went over the route of the proposed transmission line. The matter was then taken up with Mr. Caton, Manager, Electric Utility of the Winnipeg Electric Company, who has had considerable experience in the construction of transmission lines. Mr. Caton very considerately offered to look into the situation and provide us with an estimate of cost of the necessary transmission line. A copy of Mr. Caton's report is enclosed herewith.

The source of power for the Fort Alexander School would be the sub-station at the Pine Falls Paper Mill. The distance by road between the sub-station and the school is slightly less than six miles. It will possibly be preferable to have the transmission line follow the road rather than have difficulty in acquiring the right-of-way across the reserve. Furthermore, there would be considerable clearing required if the line was taken directly across the reserve and in any case some clearing will be required should the line follow the road way. Analyzing the figures submitted by Mr. Caton, we find that the cost of the transmission line will be $4,500., to which must be added the cost of transformers and cutouts at an additional $510.00. I also estimate that additional clearing will at least cost $500.00 and motors required at the plant will also cost an additional $500.00, making a total cost for installation of approximately $6,000.00.

The cost of energy has been discussed with the Manager of the Pine Falls Paper Mill and he assures me that the Paper Company will supply power at a very reasonable rate. The Manitoba Power Company are willing to give authority to the Paper Company for the sale of as much power as is required at the school.

Should the Department of Indian Affairs desire to proceed with the installation of this transmission line, it would be advisable for this Bureau to look further into the situation as regards the cost of poles and the amount of clearing required for the right-of-way.

Your obedient servant,

D. B. Gow,

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

Referring to my memorandum of the 2nd instant, regarding the quotations received for the supplying of a set of batteries for use at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School (Reserve No. 3 - Electoral District of Springfield), Man., I have to inform you that Mr. Inspector Hamilton, Winnipeg, was requested, by telegram, to state if all firms whom he asked to quote carry heavy duty batteries, similar to one on which Dickson Electric Company quotes, and, if so, to obtain their quotations and advise by wire.

While the quotation of the Dickson Electric Company is higher than that of the other firms, they guarantee their battery for seven years, in comparison with a five year guarantee of the other firms.

I would therefore recommend, in view of the longer service of their battery, that the purchase be made from the Dickson Electric Company. It is considered that their price is fair and reasonable and the type of battery on which they quote has always given entire satisfaction.

I should be pleased to have your approval for placing the order with the Dickson Electric Company, at the price quoted by them, viz.: $649.00. Funds for this purpose are available in the Appropriation for Indian Education for the current fiscal year.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dear Sir:

I recently inspected Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, but overlooked reporting the need of new work tables for the kitchen.

At present two tables are in use, and both should have been discarded years ago. These tables are about ready to fall to pieces, and beyond repair. They are covered with tin or zinc metal, and this is broken around the edge, and worn through on top. The children are continually cutting their hands, and in some cases they have been quite severe.

Another table built along the wall is also covered with metal sheeting, and this is in equally as bad condition as are the tables.

Two new tables will cost approximately $40.00, and the material and labor to cover the third table will cost approximately $10.00.

I would strongly recommend the expense necessary to make these improvements be allowed, and would appreciate having the necessary authority.

Yours truly,

My Dear Mr. Hamilton:

Further to your letter of the 21st instant, I desire to state that I proceeded to Fort Alexander last Friday accompanied by a general contractor with the intention of making an immediate start on the repairs necessary to put the laundry building in a livable condition.

We found the road on the Reserve impassable and as the material for this job would have to be hauled over this road, Father Perrault and myself came to the conclusion that nothing could be done this fall. However, I told Father Perrault that in preparation for this work next spring he could have about hundred yards of gravel hauled on the school premises. He expects to have this done this week and I told Father Perrault that he could send the account to your Department. The gravel is taken on the East side of the river and all the work will be done by the Indians on the Reserve. The reason Father Perrault and myself decided to have the gravel hauled immediately is that this is the best time of the year to secure Indian labor and the money thus spent will go a long way to reducing want among the Indians.

Hoping that you will find our decision as to the postponement of the work as well as to the purchase of the gravel in order, I remain,

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
WINNIPEG, MAN., November 1st, 1935.

Sir—

With reference to your letter 125-1-5 dated October 28th, I am now attaching copy of a letter received from Rev. Father J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.

I was on the Fort Alexander Reserve the same day as Father Plourde, October 25th, and found it impossible to reach the school by car. I made part of the trip by livery and was obliged to finish the last four miles by canoe.

The Rev. Father feels that by the time the necessary excavation is completed, it will be too cold to put in the cement. The Department will note, however, that instructions were left to secure the gravel. I understand the only place this can be obtained is across the river from the school, a distance of almost half a mile. The gravel will be brought across in small boats and the work is being carried out by the Indians. I think, in view of weather conditions, and the time it will take to do this work, a better class of work can be obtained by delaying operations until spring. The gravel could be paid for and all the necessary material purchased before the end of the fiscal year.

I would like to be advised if this meets with the Department's approval and if arrangements could be made to hold over the balance of the grant or, if not, to provide sufficient money in the 1936-37 Estimates to do the necessary construction work.

Your obedient servant,

A.G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Ottawa, November 8, 1935.

Sir:

I have your 202-11A R.C. of the first instant, enclosing copy of a communication from Reverend J. O. Plourde, O.M.I., regarding the improvements and alterations to the Laundry building at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School. The Department has noted the difficulty that will be experienced, owing to weather conditions, in having the work completed this fall, and that both Father Plourde and yourself recommend the postponement of the work until next spring.

The Department will, in view of the recommendation of Father Plourde and yourself, approve of the alterations and improvements to the laundry being carried over until next spring. In the meantime, however, in order to utilize as much of the funds as are now available for the purpose, I would request that you arrange to purchase and have delivered on the ground all materials that will be required and submit itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost, before the end of the present fiscal year. We will, no doubt, be able to provide, in the Estimates for the coming fiscal year, an amount sufficient to cover the cost of the labour in carrying out the work.

I would refer to your letter of the 21st ultimo, requesting that an accountable advance of $600 be forwarded to Mr. Agent Irwin, to pay the labour. From this amount, it may be necessary to pay the Indians for their work in supplying the gravel, which you state is being brought across the river this fall. You should request Mr. Irwin to return any balance of the advance which was made him, together with proper labour returns, in triplicate, for any payments made from this advance.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Mr. Irwin:

You will recall discussing with us the matter of a waterfront and a sink for the Indian Residential School at Fort Alexander, advising us to order the former, and get quotations and submit them to you for the sink.

Father Perrault called as arranged and gave the necessary particulars for the waterfront, which was ordered, and in due course delivered to us, and is now ready to be picked up by the School team. We could not find a sink in our catalogues that would suit the Revd. Father, and he said that he would be going to Winnipeg shortly and would look around for something suitable. We told him to make his selection, advise us all the particulars, when we would be glad to obtain prices and submit quotations to you.

We were quite surprised today to receive an invoice for the following:

1 Sink & Laundry Tray Combination with legs.
1 Enamelled Combination Sink & Laundry Tray with legs.
2 Swing Spout Faucets with metal Soap Dish
2 Adjustable Traps less Sink connection
2-1/2" N.P. Camp. S.F. Laundry Tray Faucets

The cost to the Department for this material will be $108.90, which we imagine is considerably in excess of the amount which you intended to expend. The goods were ordered shipped to Indian School c/o Rev. J. O. Plourde, Fort Alexander.

We wish to assure you that we were not in any way a party to this purchase, nor did we instruct our suppliers to deliver or ship the goods, in fact we had no correspondence whatever with them in the matter.

Will you please give us the authority to charge the goods to the Department of Indian Affairs.

Awaiting your reply, we are,

Yours very truly,

MANITOBA PAPER COMPANY LIMITED
Selkirk, Man., Jan. 29th, 1936.

Dear Sir:

We have a letter No. 125-1-5 of December 7th, 1935 which states that the Department had placed an order for seven (7) desks No. 6, Seven desks (7) No. 7, One (1) Teachers desk and two Sewing Machines for the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School.

The letter also requested me to arrange for the purchase and delivery of a water front for the kitchen range, also six (6) rubber roller casters, and casters for the beds in the infirmary.

The letter stated that the sink at present in the school is too small for their requirements and instructed me to submit an estimate of the cost of supplying a much larger sink than is in use at present, also the approximate cost of a hospital chair.

On my first visit to the Reserve after receiving the above letter, I called at the Indian Residential School and learned that the desks, sewing machines etc. had been delivered and were satisfactory.

Father Perrault, the principal of the school gave me the necessary particulars about the water front for the range and the casters but could not describe exactly the kind of sink required. I advised the principal to see Mr. Campbell, Manager of the Manitoba Paper Co.'s store at Pine Falls, and look through the catalogue with him, and if he could find the type of sink, and chair required, Mr. Campbell would be pleased to obtain prices, which I would submit to the Department at Ottawa.

A few days later, Father Perrault called at the Co's. store at Pine Falls and consulted with Mr. Campbell about the sink and chair, and as they could not find anything in the catalogue to suit, and Father Perrault intimated that he would be going to Winnipeg shortly, Mr. Campbell advised him to look around and if he found anything to suit, to bring back the particulars and he would be glad to obtain the best price and submit the same to this office, to be taken up with the Department.

Father Perrault eventually visited Winnipeg, and I enclose herewith a letter from Mr. Campbell which explains his procedure there. I may say that Father Perrault did not advise this office of his intentions re the above and we had no knowledge whatever of the transaction, until the enclosed letter was received.

The Manitoba Paper Co. are still holding the invoice and we will not authorize the same to be charged to the Department of Indian Affairs until further instructions from the Department have been received.

Kindly advise and oblige,

Your obedient servant,

Andrew Irwin,
Indian Agent.
