Sir:

In reply to Department Letter 125-1-5 dated January 24th, I am returning herewith the voucher submitted by Mr. Irwin, Indian Agent, Selkirk, amounting to $31.50, in favour of S. Perrault, Fort Alexander, Man.

On receipt of Department Letter 125-1-5 dated November 15th, 1935, I got in communication with the Rev. Father Plourde with a view to again visiting the Fort Alexander School and preparing a rough sketch of the alterations required. We were both familiar with the situation and Father Plourde stated that the only change he would suggest in the rough sketch which we had already made was to widen the passage-way to the same width as the laundry. I agreed to this suggestion, because it entailed very little additional expense. He then requested that if I could wait for a few days, he would have one of the Brothers prepare a plan, stating that in this way no mistake could occur. To accommodate Father Plourde, I agreed to wait. However, due to the Brother being sick, the plans were held up for some little time and I believe they were eventually prepared by someone else. There was no intimation that any charge would be made and, in fact, I considered a favour was being extended to Father Plourde in meeting his request.

On receipt of the voucher from the Department, I phoned Father Plourde and he appeared equally as surprised as I was and stated Father Perrault had no right to submit an account. He stated that certain expense had been incurred, but the Department were not being held responsible.

Father Plourde requested that I inform the Department that no charge was being made in connection with the plans submitted.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies - Manitoba.

In conversation with the Principal and the Rev. Father Plourde, it was decided that the passage-way, leading from the main building to the laundry, should be the full width of the building and would add very little to the cost. Dear Sir,

I understand it is the intention of the Department of Indian Affairs to repair the building formerly used as a laundry at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School.

If this information is correct, I would take the liberty of calling the attention of the Department to the fact that, unless the materials for these repairs are purchased immediately and hauled over the winter road, it will be quite late in the year, possibly next June, before the road leading through the reserve will be in fit condition for heavy draying. As the distance from Pine Falls, Man., to the school site is almost six miles, it will be readily understood that hauling a fairly large quantity of material can only be done over a reasonably good road. I understand from the Principal of the Fort Alexander School that the roads begin breaking up around the 15th of March. I hope, therefore, that all material purchased will be delivered in Pine Falls at least a few days before that date.

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O. M. I.

Operation: Steam entering the Regulator inlet, indicated by arrow, passes the semi-balanced valve—normally held open by the weighting—into the low pressure main, through the globe valve "C," into the chamber above the diaphragm, and tends to close the inner valve by gradually exerting pressure on the top of diaphragm. However, as soon as the valve is closed sufficiently to reduce the initial pressure to the predetermined low pressure, a balance is formed between the pressure above the diaphragm and the weighting. This balance permits the automatic opening or closure of the inner valve in proportion to the steam consumption, and accurately and constantly maintains the predetermined low pressure.

The by-pass valve "C" serves as a throttle to prevent vibration of the inner valve, much as a gauge cock is used to prevent vibration of the pointer on a steam gauge. On Regulators under 2 inches, this by-pass is not used, as low pressure steam passing by the stem guide bushing produces the same throttled action on the diaphragm.

In operation, this Regulator is very sensitive to slight variations in pressure, and is governed entirely by steam from the low pressure main exerting its force above the diaphragm. A bronze guide bushing with an easy sliding fit is used in preference to a leaky or binding packing box, as the valve stem is located entirely within the valve body and neck. Thus, the frictionless valve stem, in connection with the large area rubber diaphragm, permits a nicety of balance between the pressure above the diaphragm and the lever and weights. This in turn assures exceptionally sensitive regulation of the reduced pressure.

Another very desirable advantage of the No. 3 Pressure Regulator is that the visible movement of the lever and weights, responding to variations in steam demand, is a positive index of the proper functioning of the Regulator. Furthermore, lever and weights can be placed, either in line with, or at right angles to the pipe line by removing bolts and turning lower diaphragm cover.

Inner valves and seats on all sizes are bronze bevel seated, as straight side plunger valves would require excessive diaphragm movement. The diaphragm used in the Nos. 3 and 4 Pressure Regulators will last for years, as the condensation above the diaphragm prevents premature vulcanizing.

Sizes 1½ inches and under are made with bronze bodies, screwed ends only. Sizes 2 to 6 inches, inclusive, are made with iron bodies, either screwed or flanged ends; but screwed ends will be shipped unless ordered flanged. Larger sizes are made with iron bodies, flanged ends only. See page 3 for When Ordering; page 5 for List Prices, Dimensions and Weights; and page 8 for List Prices of Replacement Parts.
Klipfel No. 4 Pressure Regulator

DIAPHRAGM TYPE—EXPANDED OUTLET

Service: The No. 4 Pressure Regulator differs from the No. 3 Regulator, illustrated in section on page 1 and described on page 2, in one respect only; the outlet is made larger than the diameter of the inlet. It is especially desirable when reducing high pressure steam, air or gas to vacuum or very low pressures. When weighting is properly adjusted, this Regulator will automatically maintain a constant service pressure irrespective of boiler pressure fluctuations or changes in the demand for steam.

The expanded outlet Regulator should be used when reducing high pressure steam to a pressure low enough to require a low pressure pipe of larger size than the required inlet size of the Regulator, as both closer regulation of pressure and greater convenience in piping is thereby possible.

Sizes 1x2 and 1\(\frac{3}{4}\)x2\(\frac{1}{2}\) inches are made with bronze bodies and trimmings, screwed ends only. Regulators in sizes 1\(\frac{3}{4}\)x3 to 4x6 inches, inclusive, are made with iron bodies, bronze trimmings only. Unless otherwise ordered, these sizes will be furnished with screwed inlet and flanged outlet, although other styles of ends can be furnished, as listed on page 5. Regulators in sizes 4x8 inches and larger are made with iron bodies and bronze trimmings, flanged ends only.

When Ordering: State Regulator Number, Sizes of Inlet and Outlet, Style of Ends, Initial and desired Reduced Pressures, nature of apparatus with which Regulator is to be used and whether for the control of Steam, Air or Gas. Flanged Regulators will be furnished suitable for inlet pressures up to 125 pounds (steam) unless specified Extra Heavy, in which case both Flanges will be made Extra Heavy. When specially ordered, Extra Heavy Inlet and Standard Outlet Flanges can be furnished. Both Standard and Extra Heavy Regulators are shipped Faced and Drilled at no additional charge. Companion Flanges are extra and are furnished only when ordered. See page 1 for List of Replacement Parts; page 5 for List Prices and Dimensions; and page 8 for List Prices of Replacement Parts.
Klipfel Nos. 22, 33 and 44 Pressure Regulators

No. 22 SINGLE SEATED TYPE—(SPRING LOADED)—No. 33 SEMI-BALANCED TYPE

Service: The No. 22 Pressure Regulator may be used to reduce a comparatively low and fairly constant initial steam, air or water pressure to a pressure suitable for steam heating or domestic water supply. It is provided with a renewable composition valve disc and locking device. The latter is particularly desirable when steam or water pressure is taken from street mains. All sizes are made with bronze bodies, screwed ends only. As the area of the inner valve disc is equal in area to the full pipe area and is not balanced, orders must state accurately both the initial and the desired reduced pressures, so that a properly proportioned spring and rubber diaphragm may be supplied.

Service: The Nos. 33 and 44 Pressure Regulators are intended to reduce any initial steam, air or water pressure to any desired reduced pressure not exceeding 50 pounds. These Regulators function exactly as the Nos. 3 and 4 Regulators, described on pages 2 and 3, respectively, but differ in that a spring substitutes the weight and lever arrangement. The No. 33 is made in sizes 3\(\frac{1}{4}\) to 6 inches, inclusive, and the No. 44 is made in sizes 1x2 to 4x6 inches, inclusive.

Dear Sir:

In reply to Department Letter 125-1-5 dated May 11th, I beg to state that I visited the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School yesterday.

Although advised in your letter that the material had all been delivered, I was surprised to find the work well under way. I understand bills have been forwarded to the Department, in connection with the material, amounting to approximately $1925.72. The Rev. Father informs me there is an account for freighting, not yet submitted, of $135.30.

It was discovered yesterday that new flues will be required for the steam boiler which is being transferred from the old laundry to the new one. This work is liable to cost seventy-five or eighty dollars. The disposal line from the school to the new laundry was uncovered yesterday and it was found to be eaten through in several places. New material will be needed in connection with this. I understand that no paint has been provided and this will no doubt cost at least $30. There are many unforeseen expenses in fixing up an old building, but I think most of them have now been unearthed in connection with this work. I am of the opinion that the expense for material in regard to the laundry will total close to $2300.

The labour will be high, due to the fact that there is considerable tearing down, as well as re-building, and, in addition to the new laundry, it will be necessary.

The Secretary,

be necessary to fix up the old laundry and make it a fit place for the girls to play in. I am positive that the labour necessary will cost at least $800.

The Rev. Father has employed a foreman who appears thoroughly qualified for the work. I understand he did some work at the McIntosh Indian Residential School. The rest of the men employed are Indians. The foreman was well pleased with their work and considered he was making good progress. I am glad that the labour has been given to the Indians, because many of them are finding it very difficult to make a living.

The Principal informed me that he had a further allowance of $800 for repairs to the balconies and that he intended to do this work as soon as the laundry was completed. I would like to be advised what instructions have been issued in connection with the work at Fort Alexander as I was not aware that any of the work was under way. I informed both the Principal and Father Plourde last year that nothing further should be done in connection with the work until the plans were approved by the Department.

I would appreciate hearing from the Department regarding this matter.

Dear Sir:

I have your No. 202-11A R.C. of the 21st instant, regarding the work in completing the laundry at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School and informing the Department that this work is well under way.

Like yourself, the Department was surprised that the Principal had undertaken the work before he received the necessary authority and instructions from the Department. It is noted that the Principal has engaged the services of a competent foreman and is employing Indian labour. You should instruct the Principal to see that proper time sheets, in triplicate, are kept for all labour employed, and he should forward same to your office. If you are satisfied as to their correctness, you should certify and forward same to the Department.

The Department desires that the work in connection with the laundry be satisfactorily completed and will approve of the erection of new flues for the steam boiler, which will be transferred from the old laundry. It is noted that the cost will be approximately $80. The disposal line from the school to the new laundry should be put in thorough repair, and you may arrange for the purchase of any new material required for this purpose. You may also purchase paint, to the amount of approximately $30. Before accounts for labour and any further materials required are forwarded, the Department will be pleased if you will have the opportunity of visiting the school, inspecting the work and reporting that it has been satisfactorily finished. No doubt, it will be necessary to have the laundry machinery which was purchased some time ago installed. Will the school authorities be able to do this work, themselves, or will it be necessary to send a man for the purpose?

You should instruct the Principal at once that there are no funds to carry out repairs to the balconies and that he is not to proceed with this work if he expects the Department to be responsible for payment, until definitely advised. Until such accounts have been received in fitting up the laundry, we will be unable to decide what further amount will be available for repairs at this school. For your information, I may say that $800 is provided to complete the laundry and $400 for miscellaneous repairs.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

With reference to Department Letter 125-1-5 dated May 27th, I am now forwarding under separate cover voucher covering payment for labour in connection with the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, amounting to $625.81.

Father Perrault called at the office on May 29th and I gave him the information contained in Department letter. On the last of June, I wrote him confirming this conversation and later, on the 6th, I advised him by letter that the amount allowed for labour, namely $800., must not be exceeded. I visited the school on June 4th, and the outside of the building was completed and the new laundry machinery had been moved in. It will entail considerable work to get this machinery placed and properly connected up. There remained to be connected the heating plant, the steam boiler, and the plumbing. In addition, there was considerable work in connection with partitions etc. I consider that the work, up to that point, had been well done. Father Perrault, as well as the Foreman, advised me that it was not necessary to employ other labour in connection with installing the laundry machinery.

I have been most emphatic with Father Perrault regarding expense for labour, emphasising that the amount must not be exceeded. However, I have made it clear to Father Plourde and Father Brachet that I am of the opinion this work should not have been started under the supervision of Father Perrault. Unfortunately, I have not been able to get in communication with the Rev. Father Provincial, but I believe he is familiar with conditions at the Fort.

Sir:

Attached is Voucher No. 176 in connection with the new laundry at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, amounting to $596.20, which covers expense incurred while Rev. Father Perrault was still in charge.

The foreman is a good worker and thoroughly understands his business. Due to the change of Principals and delay in purchasing some of the material, the foreman left to work at Berens River. The laundry work will be started again and completed as soon as he returns.

I realize that the labour already has exceeded $1200, but the alterations entailed more work than was at first anticipated. We will need a further outlay for labour, but it is difficult to estimate the exact amount. I would suggest between three and four hundred dollars. The Rev. Father Brachet is now in charge and I know will give the work close supervision.

I can assure the Department that the work so far has been well done and has entailed a lot of hard labour.

I understood while in Ottawa that this work was to be completed, but the cost kept as low as possible. I have advised Father Brachet that the estimated expense has been far exceeded and that every effort must be made by him to keep any further expense at a minimum. Unless otherwise instructed, the work will be completed as soon as the foreman returns from the North.

Your obedient servant,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I beg to submit the following report in connection with the Fort Alexander R.C. Indian Residential School.

The Department is aware that the school is now in charge of the Rev. Father J. Brachet who was formerly Principal of the Pine Creek Indian Residential School, which school was exceptionally well managed and maintained in excellent condition. The Rev. Father is anxious to bring Fort Alexander up to the same high standard and I trust special consideration will be given in connection with funds necessary to put the school in good condition.

As reported in a previous letter, the laundry is still to be completed and may yet cost three or four hundred dollars for labour.

We are then faced with the question of power for the laundry. The engine now in use is about 4 H.P. and will not operate more than one unit at a time. If this kind of power is to be used, a 10 H.P. engine will be necessary and will cost approximately $700. However, I doubt the wisdom of making such a purchase if funds can be provided to connect up with the Hydro power. The present lighting plant is about finished, the batteries being the only part in good condition. We are liable, at any time, to face the need of a new lighting plant and I think the real solution to the whole problem is to bring in the Hydro power. The distance is about six miles and will cost approximately $6,000. The outlay now is fairly heavy, but it will largely do away with replacements and upkeep and will pay over a period of years. I trust every effort will be made to provide funds for this as it is urgently needed and will solve many of our present needs.

The water intake is blocked and, as there was no water for the school, the Rev. Principal immediately started digging to make the necessary repairs. It is difficult to estimate the cost as the line runs out into the river almost 300 ft. I would like authority to submit the accounts covering material and labour. Until the repairs are completed, we have absolutely no water and, of course, no fire protection.

The Principal has employed a handy man and farmer, both married. There is no house to accommodate the men.

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
the men, so the Principal started at once to erect a small cottage. The material totalled approximately $600. I think the Rev. Father would willingly supply the labour if the Department will pay for the material. I might say that practically all the labour has been given to the Indians, which is a great help; in fact, in several cases, it saved assistance in the form of relief. On the day of my inspection over thirty Indians were employed.

The building is badly in need of exterior painting. The paint is almost entirely gone from one side and the building presents a neglected appearance. I would recommend that $300 be allowed this amount to cover both material and labour. The Indians from the reserve can no doubt do the painting and they are badly in need of work.

I realize that the foregoing recommendations will entail a large expenditure and that perhaps most of it has not been provided for in the Estimates. However, the work is all urgent and some could hardly be foreseen. I sincerely hope that perhaps by delaying work less important, funds may be made available.

An early reply will be greatly appreciated.

Yours very truly,

A. G. Hamilton
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your No. 202-11A R.C. of the 7th instant, submitting a report in connection with the repairs, etc., at the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School.

It is hoped that the work in connection with the laundry is being carried to completion and that it will be finished at an early date. It is noted that the cost will exceed the amount authorized, but the Department desires that the work be satisfactorily completed and that all costs be kept to the lowest possible point, having in view the carrying out of a satisfactory job.

You are being telegraphed today regarding the repairs required to the water intake pipe as follows:

"May incur expenditure approximately Four Hundred Dollars material and labour renewing and repairing intake pipe water supply Fort Alexander Residential School."

Full particulars should be given regarding the number of days or hours employed and the rate paid the men who will perform the labour.

Regarding the small cottage which the Principal is erecting for the accommodation of the men employed at the school, I have to say that the Department will have no funds to assist in supplying the material. The Principal started this work without any reference to the Department and, as no funds were provided for the purpose, he will have to be responsible for any costs in the erection of the cottage.

A. G. Hamilton, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Winnipeg, Man.
Regarding your request that the sum of $300 be provided to paint the exterior of the school building, I regret that we will have no funds this year to carry out this work. We have incurred considerable expenditure at this school during the year and the funds allotted in our Appropriation will be exceeded in carrying out the work that has been authorized.

Regarding the question of a new engine to provide power for the laundry and new batteries for the lighting plant, I have to say that the matter of installing a power line and supplying Hydro power is receiving consideration. It is understood that, if the school be connected up with the Hydro power, it would do away with any further outlay in replacements and upkeep and would provide ample power for all services at the school. I may add, for your information only, that we will endeavour to obtain the transfer of funds which were provided in the Works Construction Appropriation (approximately $6,000) to install the power line. You will be informed later if it is possible to obtain the funds for this purpose.

In order that we will have full information as to the cost involved, the equipment required - poles, wire, etc. - and how you would propose that the work be carried out in wiring the buildings, etc., I would request that you enquire fully into the matter and advise the Department. It might be necessary to consult the Hydro authorities and ascertain their charges for delivering the power that would be required. The Hydro Company might agree to carry out certain of the work and provide some of the cost.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Dear Sir:

In confirmation of our recent conversations relative to the possible supply of electric service at Fort Alexander I would advise as follows:

The nearest point where purchased hydroelectric power is available is at the Substation of Manitoba Paper Company, Limited at Pine Falls where our 110,000 volt transmission line terminates. As it would not be economically feasible to install a special high voltage transformer at that point to serve the relatively small Fort Alexander requirements it will be necessary for us to purchase 2200 volt energy from the Paper Company's existing transformer capacity. I have tentatively discussed this with Mr. C. J. Irvine, Manager of Manitoba Paper Company and I feel we probably can count on his cooperation in that regard providing his firm are not put to any capital expenditure in providing such power.

Our estimate of the cost of bringing 3 phase 2200 volt power out of the Paper Company's Substation; of building the necessary 5½ mile circuit to Fort Alexander and installing suitable service wires, entrance boxes, distribution cabinets etc. at the Mission to supplant the Mission's present inadequate equipment, is approximately $6,000.00 providing the work is done by the Government and to our specifications. I am securing further details of this expense which I will forward as soon as it is received.

Apparently there is but a very small market for the sale of electric service in that district: Our Superintendent who recently inspected conditions reports only the following prospective users:

Indian School & residence
English Church Mission
Hudson's Bay Company
Fort Alexander Mission & School

and states the maximum connected load would be only about 40 horsepower in lights, motors, electric ranges etc. Consequently the revenue obtainable at that point would be very little even if we were to charge at the relatively high rate schedules which we have effective in the Village of Lac du Bonnet, ranging from 10¢ Kwh to 3¢ Kwh.

Until I can secure further details of the prospective revenue I can only advise that, if your Department for example are prepared to guarantee earnings to us of $750.00 annually over a five (5) year period we in turn would be willing to expend $1500.00 toward the cost of the necessary circuit to deliver service at Fort Alexander.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd) M. C. Gilman

In reply to Department Letter 125-1-5 dated August 26th, I now enclose herewith copy of a letter received from the Winnipeg Electric Company.

The Department will realize that there are several complications in connection with the installation of this power line, yet I am convinced the difficulties can be overcome. I am quite sure we can depend on the co-operation of Mr. C. C. Irvine, Manager of the Manitoba Paper Company, and I am certain we can gain the consent of the Indians to have the power line erected.

Mr. Gilman, of the Winnipeg Electric, states in the third paragraph of his letter that he figures the work could be done for approximately $6,000.00, providing we call for tenders in connection with the pole line, this work to be carried out according to specifications of the Winnipeg Electric.

If the construction of the line is undertaken, I would like to suggest that the residence at the Indian Day School be wired. This would not cost much and the teacher would no doubt be glad to pay for the electricity. It is possible that the Church of England will also wire their buildings, as well as the Hudson Bay Company. Of course, the Winnipeg Electric are anxious to sell as much power as possible and the amount of assistance given by the Company in the erection of the line depends on the sale of power. Memorandum:
The Honourable the Superintendent General,

We have been in correspondence with Inspector Hamilton of Winnipeg with reference to the installation of a power line to supply current to the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School.

The nearest point where purchased hydro power is available is at the sub-station of the Manitoba Paper Co. at Pine Falls, and it would be necessary to extend the line from this point to the school a distance of approximately 5½ miles, and the cost would be approximately $6,000.

Funds were not specifically provided for this purpose but if you approve the amount could be charged to the item in the Special Supplementary Estimates, Vote 318, which provides for the erection of Indian Day Schools.

The most satisfactory way of having the work carried out would be to make arrangements with the Winnipeg Electric Company to carry out the installation, the Department to pay them for the work. If you approve of the above the necessary instructions will be sent to Inspector Hamilton in Winnipeg to make all arrangements with the Winnipeg Electric Company for the work.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

Referring to my memorandum of September 15th, last, with reference to the installation of a power line, to supply current to the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, I would say, in reply to Mr. Pratt's enquiry by phone, that if electric power were supplied it would be utilized in operating the laundry equipment, the electric light plant, for pumping water and for general farm purposes, such as crushing grain, sawing wood, etc.

In a communication from Mr. Inspector Hamilton, Winnipeg, requesting that favourable consideration be given to the installing of the power line, he states that if same is not carried out it will be necessary to supply a 10 h.p. engine to operate the laundry equipment and also that the present lighting plant is about finished and that we are liable at any time to face the need of supplying a new lighting plant.

Inspector Hamilton states that he considers the real solution of the whole problem at this school is to bring in the Hydro power. This would largely do away with future replacements and upkeep and the cost of the work would pay over a period of a few years. Mr. Hamilton forwards details of the estimated expense from the Winnipeg Electric Company, of installing power service at the Fort Alexander Residential School, to the amount of $6,514.

Deputy Superintendent General.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I have Mr. Pratt's memorandum of the 31st ultimo, in further reference to the installation of a power line, to supply current for power purposes, to the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School.

At the present time, the power for operating the laundry equipment, electric light service and for general farm purposes is generated by gasoline engines. In March, 1924, a 7½ h.p. gasoline engine was supplied, at a cost of $322.71, to operate the laundry. New and more extensive laundry equipment was supplied during the year 1935 and considerable alterations made to the laundry building. Mr. Inspector Hamilton now states that this old engine has become unserviceable and that it will be necessary to supply a 10 h.p. engine to operate the laundry equipment.

The electric light equipment was installed in 1920, at a cost of $4,286. Since that time, there has been expended on repairs the sum of $1,694.53. A 15 h.p. engine was supplied in 1924, to operate the lighting plant, at a cost of $1,463.19. Repairs have been made to this engine and accounts paid for small repairs, from time to time, to the electric light plant. Batteries have been supplied as follows:

October, 1925, at a cost of $695.21,
December, 1931, at a cost of $597.38,
October, 1935, at a cost of $498.00.

Deputy Superintendent General.
EX'D.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

With reference to Mr. Pratt's enquiry, by phone, regarding the installation of a power line to supply current to the Fort Alexander Indian Residential School, I would say that we are not aware if the Winnipeg Electric Company, who have forwarded an estimate for the installation of the line, would consider it too late in the season to carry out the work. If desired, the Department could wire Mr. Inspector Hamilton, Winnipeg, to ascertain from the Company if they could proceed with the work this fall.

The price quoted by the Winnipeg Electric Company for the installing of the power line includes the supplying of the necessary transformers, poles, wire, switch board and labour, to the amount of $6,514. This would cover all costs that would be required in supplying current to the school for lighting and power purposes. It might take a short time for the Winnipeg Power Company to complete arrangements with the Manitoba Paper Company at Pine Falls, from whose plant the power would be obtained. If it is decided to have the Winnipeg Power Company undertake the work, the necessary instructions could be wired Mr. Inspector Hamilton, Winnipeg, who would make all arrangements with the Power Company for the installation of the line.
